Aquatic Conservation Strategy
Objectives

Effect of treatments from the various action alternatives in relation to
the ACS

6.) Maintain and restore in-stream
flows sufficient to create and
sustain riparian, aquatic, and
wetland habitats, and to retain
patterns of sediment, nutrient, and
wood routing. The timing,
magnitude, duration, and spatial
distribution of peak, high and low
flows must be protected.

Existing Conditions: The mainstem Trinity River has an inter-basin transfer that
has transported Trinity River water to the Sacramento River Basin since 1963.
Unless this diversion is discontinued there is no way to restore instream flows to
historic conditions. The South Fork Trinity River however is the largest
remaining undammed river in California. Over the last decade with the increase
in cannabis plantations a considerable increase in illegal water drafting has also
resulted. Late summer flows have nearly been depleted by this drafting in many
of the perennially flowing tributaries.

1T

7.) Maintain and restore the timing,
variability, and duration of floodplain
inundation and water table
elevation in meadows and
wetlands.

The 2015 wildfires will result in slight increases in adjacent tributary peak flows
and are also likely to have augmented low flows as fewer trees are utilizing
moisture due to the replacement of living trees with dead trees on large scales..
This increase in flow is negligible in comparison to the flow alterations described
above.
This project proposes no new road construction that could otherwise result in
surface runoff increases. Legacy road site treatments will decrease the
possibility of site diversions at later dates. The most direct way that instream
flows could be modified by this project would be during the time it takes to draft
water from designated sites long enough to fill water tank vehicles. Both LRMP
and NMFS water drafting standards and drafting specifications included as
Appendix E in the Project Fish BE will be closely adhered to, which will minimize
such impacts to acceptable levels when drafting occurs. Otherwise, there is no
aspect of any of the potential action alternatives that could appreciably affect
instream flows or the natural hydrographs of such flows.
Project implementation via any of the action alternatives will not prevent
attainment of this ACS objective at the Project site scale or in the short term
(aided greatly by Project EEZs, BMPs, and RPMs), and meets the objective at
the landscape scale and in the intermediate to long-term.
Existing Conditions: floodplains along the mainstem Trinity River have
experienced impacts from historic mining activities with tailing piles stacked
throughout portions of them that have dramatically decreased flood prone
areas. Seeps and springs throughout the areas burned by the 2015 wildfires are
receiving higher than normal rates of soil saturation due to the loss of mature
green trees. Therefore small areas of perennial soil saturation are likely
providing additional aquatic habitats that were more limited before the wildfires.
Proposed treatments where hazard trees are felled into perennial streams could
alter local site patterns of floodplain inundation, water table elevation. However,
it would have no effect or only minor effect to existing flow patterns and stream
channel conditions. Floodplains, meadows, springs and wetlands are all
included within Riparian Reserve designations. No ground disturbing activities
would take place within these areas and the proposed activities would not affect
timing, variability, and duration of floodplain inundation.
Treated areas may have increased soil moisture but not enough to measurably
affect water table elevations. Protecting riparian areas as well as not
constructing system roads or operating within floodplains would help to maintain
existing conditions. Proposed treatments will maintain and restore the variability
of floodplain inundation. There will be no effect on wetlands. Project
implementation via any of the action alternatives will not prevent attainment of
this ACS objective at the Project site scale or in the short term (aided greatly by
Project EEZs, BMPs, and RPMs), and meets the objective at the landscape
scale and in the intermediate to long-term.

8. Maintain and restore the species
composition and structural diversity
of plant communities in riparian
areas and wetlands to provide
adequate summer and winter
thermal regulation, nutrient filtering,
appropriate rates of surface
erosion, bank erosion, and channel
migration and to supply amounts
and distributions of coarse woody
debris sufficient to sustain physical
complexity and stability.

Existing Conditions: The 2015 fires did not significantly alter structural
distributions of plant communities in riparian areas with a maximum of 11% of
Upper Hayfork Watershed burned at moderate and high burn severities. At a subdrainage scale (HUC8) the 2015 wildfire effects to the hydrologic units are much
more pronounced. Sixty-five percent of the 159 sub-drainages had more than 5%
of the area burned at high and moderate severities. Six percent of these (9 subdrainages) had more than 50% burn at high and moderate severities. Six of these
were dispersed in different drainages, but 3 of them are in the Chanchelulla –
Shiell Gulch drainage that all drain into the Dubakella Sub-drainage. The fire in
these areas adversely altered thermal regulation, nutrient filtering and erosion
rates at reach scales.

1T

Existing and Future Activities – (not including this project)
The reforestation projects of private and public lands will help to restore the
continuity in vegetation along streams restoring the thermal insulation, which will
take roughly 30 years to develop shading to pre fire conditions.
Proposed treatments would not alter the restoration of the species composition
and structural diversity of plant communities in untreated areas. Riparian
vegetation would be protected as required by resource protection measures and
EEZs. Large overstory vegetation would remain intact except where hazard trees
are already dead, and would continue to provide thermal regulation. So hazard
trees within 150 feet of streams would be felled to become LWD but the healthy
trees remain to become future LWD. In the long-term, treatments in riparian
reserves are expected to promote the growth of larger conifer and hardwood
species already present, resulting in a more diverse forest structure and a source
of coarse woody debris. Project activities move treated riparian reserves towards
being more resilient to wildfire and maintain riparian processes and function.
Project implementation via any of the action alternatives will not prevent
attainment of this ACS objective at the Project site scale or in the short term
(aided greatly by Project EEZs, BMPs, and RPMs), and meets the objective at the
landscape scale and in the intermediate to long-term.

Objectives

Effect of treatments from the various action alternatives in relation to

9. Maintain and restore habitat to
support well-distributed populations
of native plant, invertebrate, and
vertebrate riparian-dependent
species

Existing Conditions: The South Fork Trinity River has a TMDL in place (EPA
1998) to restore aquatic habitat conditions by reducing sedimentation. The
mainstem Trinity River also has a sediment TMDL in place (EPA 2001). The
New River Watershed which is a tributary to the main stem Trinity River is
designated as a Key Watershed in the STNF LRMP and is considered as high
quality habitat providing refugia for aquatic species. It is also considered a
reference watershed that was utilized to set the TMDL and is also clear of
mercury issues.
Existing and Future Activities – (not including this project)
The reforestation projects of private and public lands will help to restore the
continuity in vegetation along streams restoring the thermal insulation which will
take roughly 30 years to develop shading to pre fire conditions.
The proposed treatments in the action alternatives are designed in part to
reduce fuel loading and move the fire regime closer to that which occurred
historically on the landscape and within riparian reserves. No adverse impacts
to aquatic species are expected to occur in or downstream of the Project area
as a result of the Project in the short term. Beneficial effects to riparian and
aquatic habitat are expected in the long-term.
Proposed treatments which include the connected actions of treating legacy
sediment sites would contribute to the more immediate restoration of local
habitat above and below stream crossings that are improved as a condition of
the enrollment of this project under the North Coast Regional Water Quality
Waiver. Over the long term these actions are expected to support welldistributed populations of riparian-dependent species by increasing habitat
continuity, reducing sediment loads and speeding the development of latesuccessional forest characteristics, including large trees and a multi-story
canopy, in the Riparian Reserve areas that would receive fuels treatments.
Proposed treatments could cause a very minor short-term reduction in canopy
closure in the Riparian Reserve areas having individual hazard trees felled, but
any effect on species would be negligible because of the over-riding effect of
the residual trees and because of the small proportion of the Riparian Reserve
that would be treated. Habitat would be restored spatially and temporally.
Project implementation via any of the action alternatives will not prevent
attainment of this ACS objective at the Project site scale or in the short term
(aided greatly by Project EEZs, BMPs, and RPMs), and meets the objective at
the landscape scale and in the intermediate to long-term.

APPENDIX H-DRAFT ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT
STATEMENT COMMENTS AND RESPONSES
Comments and Responses
1. C onservation Congress - Denise Boggs
50T

Comment: "The Conservation Congress - Denise Boggs (CC) and Safe Alternatives for our
Forest Environment - Larry Glass (S.A.F.E.) appreciate the opportunity to comment on the DEIS
for the Trinity Post Fire Hazard Reduction and Salvage Project (hereafter referred to as project).
We request our comments be considered prior to making a final decision.
CC provided scoping comments on this project and while they are already in the administrative
record, we incorporate them again here. We also incorporate by reference the comments and
attachments submitted by WNI during both scoping and this DEIS comment period. The DEIS
fails to address many of the issues raised during scoping."
Response: Thank you for your continued interest in the management of the Shasta-Trinity
National Forest. All comments submitted during the comment period on the DEIS were
considered and responded to. Since you have not identified any specific comments for which the
responses were inadequate, we are unable to determine what issues you believe were not
adequately addressed.

2. C onservation Congress - Denise Boggs
50T

Comment: In our scoping comments, we asked how the areas selected for logging were chosen.
The FS responded that roads identified for salvage were based on economic viability. This
generally means large diameter trees. There is no mention or charts of the DBHs in the project
area but the economic analysis mentions an average of 25" DBH. Considering the number of owl
territories and designated critical habitat in the project, we don't believe it was appropriate to use
economics as the driving factor, and it certainly isn't in concert with the ESA. The roads were
evaluated using GIS and then overlaid with RAVG fire severity data. According to Appendix 2:
RAVG Calibration the calibration is not accurate with an upper and lower confidence level of
42.71% - 33.76% respectively. "All one can say about the results is there is a difference and that
difference is approximately 40%." This is important because the areas the RAVG found to have
burned at moderate intensity are being considered as high intensity for this project. The FS claims
some of the sites likely experienced moderate fire severity, but the calibration provides a much
more accurate overall estimation of the actual effects of the fire on vegetation. We would disagree
that a 60% accuracy rate, which would be a "D" grade at maximum is providing a more accurate
estimation. Considering moderate burned trees as high burned trees could result in green trees
being logged, when the project is proposed as cutting only dead trees.
Response: First, it is important to note that salvage and hazard tree felling are different actions.
Salvage deals with the sale and removal of felled trees (logging), while hazard tree falling does
not involve logging. The purpose of this project is to mitigate hazards that threaten public safety
along open roads, sustain and establish forest cover, and capture economic value and support the
economies of local communities by providing forest products. While capturing economic value
(e.g. salvage logging) is a component of the Purpose and Need it is not the primary driver as
much as a tool to achieve the goals of hazard mitigation. As hazard mitigation will occur along all
open roads in the fire footprints, the major benefit of salvage logging is that it will offset the cost
of some of the fuel treatment activities since, otherwise, fuels treatments alone would have to
mitigate the increase in fuel loads created by addition of numerous felled trees to the forest floor.
As indicated in the response to your Scoping Comment 35 (DEIS pg. 391), the economic
opportunity or viability of any one treatment area was a determining factor in its inclusion in a
559

Final Environmental Impact Statement

Trinity Post Fire Hazard Reduction and Salvage

timber sale, not in the need for hazard mitigation. Areas with larger diameter trees generally have
a higher value than areas of smaller trees due in part to deterioration rates. These areas do not
necessarily correlate to northern spotted owl occupancy. Note that the scope of the project is
limited to the roadside hazards, thereby forgoing the areas of high economic viability that would
generally be associated with a salvage sale (see Alternative 9).
This comment includes some confusion over RAVG calibration. RAVG data looks at mortality of
a stand immediately following the fire; however, trees often continue to die due to secondary
mortality. As greater mortality was observed in the field than was represented in the RAVG data,
additional plots were taken a few months after RAVG was processed. The plot data indicated that
within moderate to high burn severity areas, mortality was approximately 40% higher (these are
not "confidence intervals" but percentage underestimate) than indicated by RAVG, due to
secondary mortality. This calibration increases the accuracy of analysis which may have
previously underestimated the impacts of the fires and therefore the hazards associated with it.
RAVG calibration does not in any way change the prescriptions associated with the project,
which only treats dead trees (under Alternatives 1, 4 and 5). If an area identified for salvage
logging has a majority of live, healthy trees that will not change the requirement that only the
dead trees within that stand may be cut. Implementation takes into account the conditions on the
ground, not projected conditions, when determining if a tree is dead.

3. C onservation Congress - Denise Boggs
50T

Comment: Since 66% of the roads in the project are class 2 and not open to passenger level
vehicles, we don't see an urgent need to "protect" these areas from alleged hazards.
Response: The Purpose and Need on page 4 of the DEIS states: "Mitigate hazards (i.e. fire-killed
or defective trees and excessive fuels) that threaten public safety along open National Forest
System, County, and State roads." This purpose for the project defines the scope of treatments
that are necessary, and limits the opportunity to analyze alternatives that either treat more or less
than those roads that are open to the public. This project is responding to conditions that already
exist. The fires have already burned and caused hazards along roads that are open to the public.
To exclude one type of road over another because of the type of vehicle and the assumed use
seems arbitrary and capricious. Alternative 7: Treat Along High Use Roads Only was considered
but eliminated from detailed study due to it not meeting the Purpose and Need. A different
Purpose and Need or another project might allow for a different range of miles analyzed, but that
is not being considered at this time.

included in the mileage numbers. It isn't clear whether the project will treat these unauthorized
routes.
Response: The intent of the footnote (BA, page 12) is to recognize that there may be other routes
in the project area, but are not included in the project because they are not authorized or open to
the public. These routes will not have a treatment along them under any alternative. The footnote
does not seem to be adding the desired clarification so it will be removed.

There is simply no excuse not to conduct the proper analyses as we outline in comments below.
One of the primary Purpose and Needs for the project is to recover the economic value of timber.
That boat sailed as the DEIS confirms. If the project is logged after 2016, not only will the timber
lose its value but the sale will be well below cost. In light of this we believe the DEIS should be

50T

560

Final Environmental Impact Statement

Trinity Post Fire Hazard Reduction and Salvage

would likely be smaller in scale and far less harmful to imperiled species and their habitat, as well
as other resource values."
Response: As identified in Chapter 1 of the DEIS, the purposes of this project are to mitigate
hazards that threaten public safety, sustain and establish forest cover and capture economic value.
While large salvage timber sales would go farther to offset costs associated with hazard
mitigation, some economic value can still be captured by the public through other means such as
firewood cutting, biomass sales and small sales. More importantly, the hazards to the public are
still present and still need to be addressed. The Forest has conducted substantive and appropriate
analysis for all affected resources. Economics has not been the primary driver for this project, as
indicated (in part) by the Forest's decision not to seek an ESD. Many factors impacted the Forest's
decision not to seek an ESD, but the level of analysis required with or without an ESD is
unchanged.

7. C onservation Congress - Denise Boggs
50T

Comment: In addition, of the 233 miles only 27 miles have been designated as high value
wildlife conservation areas due to their value as habitat for NSO. Over half of the project is in
designated critical habitat so far more than 27 miles of roads should have been included in this
designation.
Response: The US Forest Service worked closely with the US Fish and Wildlife Service to
determine the area’s most valuable to NSO, which are designated here as High-Value Wildlife
Conservation Areas. This process is described in detail on pp. 32-34 of the BA. It incorporated
NSO habitat mapping, the US Fish and Wildlife Service Relative Habitat Suitability modeling,
and survey results identifying areas known to be used by nesting or pair-bonded NSO. This
process helped focus protection measures on the most valuable areas, while still allowing the
project's Purpose and Need to be met.
Over half of the project area is within designated NSO Critical Habitat Units (CHUs). However,
CHUs include many areas that do not meet the definition of suitable NSO habitat, and many areas
that are marginal in their capability to support NSO populations. These factors are reflected in the
US Fish and Wildlife Service's Relative Habitat Suitability modeling, which was utilized in the
process of mapping HVWCAs. Although this process did not identify all lands within NSO

Critical Habitat Units (CHUs) as High-Value Wildlife Conservation Areas, resource protection
measures still require retention of coarse woody debris in these areas, albeit at lower levels than
within the HVWCAs.

11. C onservation Congress - Denise Boggs
50T

Comment: According to the BA, multiple aspects of suitable habitat are required for habitat to be
considered suitable or high quality. These habitat elements can't be queried from the E-veg data.
As a result, the actual quantity of suitable habitat may be overestimated. The FS also did not field
validate 75% of the habitat due to the size of the project area. The 25% that was field validated
either before or after the fire showed the NSO habitat layer is generally an accurate assessment of
NRF habitat on the ground. There are problems with this assumption. Validating habitat before
the fire should have given different results than after the fire. The project area is large and has
diverse typography. The quality of habitat components in a flatter area may be different than in a
steep area. The FS simply can't extrapolate the entire project area's suitable habitat based on field
validation of only ¼ of the project. And, since the E-veg overestimated the quality of suitable
habitat that means the level of impacts were likely underestimated.
50T

563

Final Environmental Impact Statement

Trinity Post Fire Hazard Reduction and Salvage

Response: The habitat field verification that was done before the fires was used to validate prefire habitat conditions. The e-veg habitat database was also used, as well as pre-fire aerial
imagery. The pre-fire habitat conditions were then used in combination with RAVG and post-fire
field verification to map post-fire habitat conditions. E-veg was found to be generally accurate
but more likely to overestimate rather than underestimate the amount of suitable NSO habitat
present. The result of this would not be to under-represent potential effects to NSO habitat, but
instead to over-estimate these potential effects.

12. C onservation Congress - Denise Boggs
50T

Comment: The project was determined to "likely to adversely affect NSO Critical habitat"
because snag density and CWD levels in suitable habitat will be reduced to a point that will cause
detrimental impacts to habitat and therefore harm the viability of NSO. The DEIS claims some
impacts will be alleviated by RPMs but as we document below this is untrue because the LOPs
can be lifted and no surveys were conducted for owls.
Response: The project design includes numerous resource protection measures (RPMs) that will
reduce potential effects to NSO, including coarse woody debris and snag retention requirements
(DEIS, pp. 30-31), and LOPs. As detailed in RPMs, the LOPs can only be lifted if protocol
surveys are completed and non-nesting is determined. The main effects leading to the "likely"
determination for critical habitat are effects to snags and CWD (especially snags), but there are no
set thresholds established in the analysis below which a "likely" determination is triggered. The
determination was a function of degradation of suitable NRF habitats (and removal of PFF)
across a large enough acreage that it may be above the level of insignificant or discountable (or
wholly beneficial).The viability of NSO is determined by FWS and will be documented in their
BO.

13. C onservation Congress - Denise Boggs
50T

Comment: The DEIS did not include an Environmental Baseline as required under the ESA, so
we assume the FS is relying completely on the FWS for this analysis. That analysis is not
available for review and public comment. As we document in the NEPA cumulative effects
comments, there has been a significant amount of logging in owl habitat in the past, present and
there will be in the future when private lands logging is combined with FS logging. An analysis of
the entire CHU will not be sufficient and the EB must include the three subunits in the analysis.
Response: As required under ESA, the BA includes an analysis of effects of the Preferred
Alternative on suitable NSO habitat and Critical Habitat in the project action area (pp. 76-85).
Cumulative effects includes the effects of past activities and ongoing and future activities. The
effects of past activities are captured by the assessment of current conditions (i.e. the existing
environment). The habitat mapping used in the BA represents these current conditions. Ongoing
and future foreseeable activities, including post-fire timber salvage harvest on private lands, are
analyzed in the BA (pp. 70-76).The US Fish and Wildlife Service Biological Opinion will address
overall effects to all Critical Habitat Units that are affected by project activities. This analysis will
utilize the current habitat conditions in the project action area that are identified in the BA, as
well as other habitat mapping developed by the US Fish and Wildlife Service. That document will
be available to the public with the FEIS. Under ESA, the FWS (not the Forest Service) updates
the environmental baseline and it will be included in the BO.

considered valuable components of NSO habitat that enhance NSO foraging opportunities within
both nesting/roosting and foraging habitats. Openings of such small size are also not considered a
meaningfully measurable impediment to NSO dispersal. The project design also prohibits
mechanical or tractor-based operations in NSO nesting/roosting habitats within high-value
wildlife conservation areas (DEIS p. 30). This RPM would not allow landings to be used in these
areas.

16. C onservation Congress - Denise Boggs
50T

Comment: The BA is silent on whether snag requirements per the LRMP will be met. In fact the
BA is entirely silent on LRMP standards and guidelines in general.
Response: The purpose of the Biological Assessment (BA) is to analyze the potential effects of
the proposed action on threatened or endangered wildlife species listed under the Federal
Endangered Species Act (ESA) and on their designated critical habitat. There is no requirement
under ESA to ensure project compliance with Forest Plan standards and guidelines - that would
fall under NFMA and/or NEPA compliance which is incorporated into the EIS. The BA does
detail resource protection measures related to snags within and outside of HVWCAs, as well as
the effect of treatments on snag levels (which affects habitat quality) within roadside buffer.
Resource Protection Measures #2(a)(iii) and #2(b)(ii), which were developed collaboratively with
the FWS, identify snag retention requirements specific to this project. Under the Forest Plan
(LSR), snag retention is to be maintained at "naturally occurring levels" (Forest Plan 4-44).
Within Matrix land allocations, a minimum of 1.5 snags (greater than 15-inches in diameter) per
acre averaged over up to 40 acres (Forest Plan 4-62) is required. Hazard trees will be felled
regardless of the number of snags present. However, snags not posing a hazard that do not meet
merchantability specifications [as is the case for many of the snags killed by fire (see Economics
section of Chapter 3)], that contain blue stain (i.e. ponderosa pine), or that are inaccessible by
end-lining on steep slopes would be left standing within the buffer at levels consistent with or
exceeding Forest Plan guidelines. Considering this project only treats a narrow linear buffer along
open roads, the rest of the 90-95% (depending on alternative) of the NFS lands affected by
wildfire in 2015 but not a part of this project would retain well above 1.5 snags per acre. While
variable, snag data collected in late fall following the 2015 wildfires indicated an average of over
60 snags/acre (greater than 15-inches dbh) in areas of mature forest that burned at moderate to
high intensity. Similar conditions can be assumed for moderate and high severity areas adjacent to
the treatment buffers. See Vegetation section of Chapter 3.
50T

17. C onservation Congress - Denise Boggs
50T

Comment: The project proposes to plant the logged areas using a mixed conifer, and the BA
states NSO infrequently use ponderosa pine habitat. Yet we have seen almost every project in owl
habitat on the STNF plant a primary pine component after logging mixed conifer. The BA and
DEIS fail to provide the percentage of the seed mix that will be used for planting and we have
50T

565

Final Environmental Impact Statement

Trinity Post Fire Hazard Reduction and Salvage

requested this information previously. The BA states ponderosa pine is included in the mix but
not the percentage. We request this information be disclosed in the FEIS.
Response: The specific mix is not disclosed, as it is varies depending on existing stand
conditions. The alternative descriptions indicate that a "species composition consistent with
historic conditions" will be utilized. This project crosses multiple stand types, as it follows open
roads impacted by wildfire in a linear fashion. Therefore, it is difficult and somewhat
disingenuous to identify a one-size-fits-all-stands prescription for mix of species planted.
Ponderosa and sugar pine are incorporated into the species mix in mixed conifer stands, if they
were present historically, as they are a component of mixed conifer. Generally speaking, only the
Blue Fire contains large pine-dominated stands that would be planted back to primarily pine. True
mixed conifer stands are generally planted to at least 50% Douglas-fir.

18. C onservation Congress - Denise Boggs
50T

Comment: "The DEIS and BA do not have an analysis of any of the LSRs in the project area, yet
the map shows LSRs throughout the project. They should have been including documenting each
name/number, the level of current NRF habitat, how they are functioning, occupancy information,
and past, present and current impacts. This analysis is not the same as that for critical habitat even
though they may overlap. This information needs to be included in the FEIS.
For example, in one LSR that we know of the Gemmill project is planned in about ½ of the LSR.

project. An analysis of these impacts to that LSR must be done. Is LSRA direction being met in
this project?”
Response: LSRA direction is being met by this project. The LSR allocation is managed under
Forest Plan Prescription VII, Late-Successional Reserves and Threatened, Endangered, and
Selected Sensitive Species. In accordance with NWFP Standards and Guidelines (USDA and
USDI, , 1994a pp. C-11) the Forest prepared the Late-Successional Reserve Assessment (LSRA)
which was concurred with by the Regional Ecosystems Office in a 1999 memorandum. The
purpose of the LSRA was to develop management strategies for the LSRs, determine their
sustainability, and provide information to decision makers for managing LSRs to meet Forest
Plan goals and objectives. LSRs are a land allocation and therefore shape project design to ensure
consistency, but do not require an additional analysis. The project is consistent with LSRA
Activity Design Criteria #7 Fuel Reduction (primarily dead and down which applies to areas
greater than 10 acres that have received a stand-replacing event). Habitat suitability for northern
spotted owls is analyzed in the EIS and BA as it relates to designated Critical Habitat, which is a
more meaningful analysis. The Shiell Fire (a component of the Fork Complex, and one of the
more difficult to contain due to low road densities) moved through the Chanchelulla LSR
naturally. Minor backburning occurred to effectively slow down the fire and prevent it from
burning through the entirety of the LSR, but was not the source of fire within the LSR.

50T

Comment: We also could not find any documents showing compliance with the NWFP. Does the

watersheds containing less than 15% of such stands. Is this standard being met in the project
area?"
Response: In accordance with the NWFP, the Shasta-Trinity Land and Resource Management
Plan (Forest Plan) required completion of Late Successional Reserve Assessments (LSRAs) that
would provide guidance for management in the LSRs. A Forest-level LSRA was completed in
1999 and concurred with by REO in an August 26, 1999 memorandum. The memorandum
specifies that "silvicultural and hazard reduction treatments described in Chapter 4 of the LSRA
are exempted from subsequent project-level REO review." This project is consistent with the
LSRA's Activity Design Criterion #7 Fuels Reduction (primarily dead and down) for areas greater
than 10 acres that have received a stand-replacing event, as disclosed in Chapter 1. As a result,
REO review is not required for this project.
The Forest Plan and the NWFP ROD require management for retention of at least 15% late
successional conditions in each 5th field planning watershed (Forest Plan, page 4-71; USDA and
USDI, 1994a page C-44). The relevant NWFP Standard and Guideline clarifies that it applies to
late-successional forest (second paragraph), of which the Forest recognizes old-growth to be a
significant and important subset. Implementation of this project would not downgrade or remove
50T

50T

50T

50T

567

Final Environmental Impact Statement

Trinity Post Fire Hazard Reduction and Salvage

any nesting and roosting or foraging habitat. Therefore all existing late successional and oldgrowth habitats would be maintained. Resource Protection Measures #2(a)(iii) and #2(b)(ii),
which were developed collaboratively with the FWS, identify snag retention requirements
specific to this project. Under the Forest Plan (LSR), snag retention is to be maintained at
"naturally recurring levels" (Forest Plan 4-44). Within Matrix land allocations, a minimum of 1.5
snags (greater than 15-inches in diameter) per acre averaged over up to 40 acres (Forest Plan 462) is required. Hazard trees will be felled regardless of the number of snags present. However,
snags not posing a hazard that do not meet merchantability specifications [as is the case for many
of the snags killed by fire (see Economics section of Chapter 3)], that contain blue stain (i.e.
ponderosa pine), or that are inaccessible by end-lining on steep slopes would be left standing
within the buffer at levels consistent with or exceeding Forest Plan guidelines. In addition,
considering this project only treats a narrow linear buffer along open roads, the rest of the 9095% (depending on alternative) of the NFS lands affected by wildfire in 2015 but not a part of
this project would retain well above 1.5 snags per acre. While variable, snag data collected in late
fall following the 2015 wildfires indicated an average of over 60 snags/acre (greater than 15inches dbh) in areas of mature forest that burned at moderate to high intensity. Similar conditions
can be assumed for moderate and high severity areas adjacent to the treatment buffers. See
Vegetation section of Chapter 3.

Comment: These areas were chosen by the FS as preferable to NSO and within critical habitat;
within a core area of a territory that has a history of nesting or a resident pair, and preferable

Within the HVWCAs, in addition to NRF habitat, there is also PFF designated habitat: post fire
foraging habitat within 500 feet of currently suitable NRF habitat. Current science defines PFF
out to 1.5 km (Bond 2009) and the 500 feet figure is arbitrary and made up by the FS for this
project. It also permits more logging closer to the core area. This habitat was NRF habitat prior to
the fire and is considered important to foraging NSO. Impacts to PFF are deemed detrimental;
therefore degrading or removal of PFF is included in determinations for NSO territories. The
project will remove 221 acres of PFF. It appears the point of designating HVWCAs is somewhat
obviated by reducing the PFF to 500 feet from the core areas.
Hazard trees will be removed in these areas. Salvage logging will occur in all suitable NRF
habitat as well as PFF habitat outside of the HVWCAs."
Response: The 1.5 km figure in Bond (2009) is a recommendation to protect burned habitats
within 1.5 km of California spotted owl activity centers. The 500-foot figure in the analysis for
the proposed project is entirely different. It is an estimate of how far into burned areas a northern
spotted owl is most likely willing to fly from the edge of suitable nesting/roosting or foraging
habitats to forage in burned (post-fire foraging) areas. This distance is independent of the distance
from an NSO activity center. As a result, these habitats (PFF1 habitats) within High-Value
Wildlife Conservation Areas receive enhanced resource protection measures regardless of their
distance from an NSO activity center. This RPM is designed to reduce effects and still allow the
Purpose and Need to be met, not to eliminate any impacts in PFF or NRF habitats. The criteria for
determining High-Value Wildlife Conservation Areas is in the "Methods for Designating HighValue Wildlife Conservation Areas" section of the BA (p. 32). In addition, some NSO core areas
that did not meet the definition of "high-value" were nonetheless considered as high-value at the
recommendation of the US Fish and Wildlife Service (none were removed from high-value status
as a result of these discussions).
Project activities may affect all types of NSO habitats, including PFF habitats. These effects are
described in detail in the "Effects to NSO Habitat" section of the BA (pp. 46-53). As stated by the
commenter, the determinations for effects include PFF habitat.

Comment: Back in 2010, CC filed an NOI against the STNF for failing to keep an updated
Environmental Baseline; failing to keep track of owl take; and failure to produce monitoring
reports required in the LRMP. In response, the FS produced these reports and posted them on the
website. Since then, nothing has been posted since the 2009 report on the website to demonstrate
the STNF is keeping an updated EB; keeping track of owl take; and keeping track of owl
populations. Since the STNF refuses to conduct protocol surveys for NSO, it is impossible to
produce these reports with any level of certainly.
In this project surveys have not been conducted either although 92 NSO activity centers are
documented in the project. Simply producing a DEIS and determining likely to adverse effects to
owls and critical habitat, does not alleviate the STNF from its ESA responsibilities."
Response: The comment refers to several tasks in the analysis of project effects on ESA listed
species. Some of these tasks are the responsibility of the Forest Service, as the action agency, and
some of the tasks are the responsibility of the USFWS , as the regulatory agency. The
environmental baseline is a requirement of the jeopardy analysis and is generally maintained by
the regulatory agency, as in this case, with the help of the action agency. The USFWS maintains a
status database that provides USFWS biologists with an accounting of incidental take throughout
the range (including the Shasta-Trinity National Forest). This provides a thorough analysis of
569
50T

50T

Final Environmental Impact Statement

Trinity Post Fire Hazard Reduction and Salvage

both owl take and known occupied and unoccupied owl activity centers, and informs the final
decision-making by the Forest Service decision-maker. Streamlined consultation allows the
USFWS to actively participate in the development of the project integrating these larger scale
concerns into the project design itself. The action agency develops a Biological Assessment (BA)
to analyze the direct, indirect, and cumulative effects of the action on individual animals within
the project area and the critical habitat, and supplies this analysis to the regulatory agency. The
regulatory agency must formally accept the BA when they have determined that it provides all the
necessary information to complete consultation. The BA, in combination with the information
that the regulatory agency manages on the species, enables the regulatory agency to complete
their portion of the analysis and render a Biological Opinion.

25. C onservation Congress - Denise Boggs
50T

Comment: "The FS has failed to conduct protocol surveys using the 2012 protocol. It attempts to
excuse this by claiming it is assuming occupancy in all owl activity centers and limits its analysis
of impacts to NSO to the activity centers. This approach fails for several reasons. The DEIS
concedes barred owls are in the project area and in some of the activity centers. Because of that,
there almost certainly are NSO living in suitable habitat outside activity centers. The reality is the
FS has no idea where owls are actually located. We encountered this very situation on the
neighboring Mendocino NF. NSO were found nesting outside activity centers likely due to the
presence of barred owls, as well as loss of suitable habitat in the activity center. Even the
proposed stand searches during project implementation are limited to core areas only and not
suitable NRF habitat. By not conducting protocol surveys, take of NSO will almost certainly
occur.
Table 7 shows the reproductive status of each activity center and most of the information is very
old going back to 1982. A few of the territories had surveys in 2015 but not many."
Response: There is no requirement under the ESA for protocol surveys to be conducted, and the
US Fish and Wildlife Service reiterated during the planning process for this project that a valid
effects analysis can be conducted without protocol survey results being available for the entire
action area. Because much of the project area has not been recently surveyed, the analysis in the
BA properly assumes that suitable habitats in these areas may be occupied by NSO. Potential
effects of barred owls on NSO are discussed in the BA (pp. 22, 33, 52-53 and 100). The potential
for barred owls to affect NSO responsiveness is a primary reason why protocol surveys, which
have been conducted for a portion of the project area, now consist of six site visits per year rather
than three. NSO in this area frequently move their activity centers. It is not possible to determine
why movement occurred in any given activity center, but known moves are documented in the
available survey results, and the analysis does not assume that suitable habitat outside known
activity centers is unoccupied. The potential for other activity centers to move due to barred owls,
wildfire, or other causes is information that is obviously not available where protocol surveys
have not been conducted recently. However, Table 5 in the wildlife BA summarizes effects to
suitable habitats in the entire action area, including the areas outside of known NSO territories,
and "take" of NSO across the entire action area will be determined by the US Fish and Wildlife
Service in their Biological Opinion for this project. The stand searches in cores within LOP
exemption areas will reduce the likelihood of "take" of NSO. However, the determination for
these territories in the BA is still "may affect, likely to adversely affect" to acknowledge the
potential for disturbance to NSO in these territories despite the stand searches.

Final Environmental Impact Statement

Trinity Post Fire Hazard Reduction and Salvage

Response: The cumulative effects analysis area includes any area within 1.3 miles of a treatment
area. That is the radius of a typical NSO territory in this area, and is thus used to define the NSO
action area for potential effects of this project to NSO. This parameter was established by the
Yreka Office of the US Fish and Wildlife Service, the agency of expertise on NSO.
Temporal bounding for this analysis is both short term and long term. The short-term bounding is
the time during project implementation because it is tied directly to the potential for noise
disturbance and immediate habitat alteration. The estimated timeline for hazard tree abatement,
fuel loading reduction, wood product removal and planting implementation is up to 5 years, and
maintenance actions may occur up to 20 years into the future.
Long-term bounding is determined by several factors. First, we looked at the habitat elements for
NSO and determined that snag density and down logs were the elements that would be affected
by the project for greatest amount of time. Then, we determined that the effects of this project on
snags and down logs would not be meaningful approximately 40 years after implementation (60
years post-fire). In current NSO nesting/roosting, foraging and dispersal habitats, the reduction in
snag numbers due to this project will be counteracted within 60 years through ongoing mortality,
including additional tree mortality from the effects of the 2015 fires. This tree mortality is also
expected to provide a high density of down logs in these habitats. This bounding is used to fully
account for any type of impacts although it exaggerates the reduction of snags and down logs due
to the narrow treatment area along open roads. Note that even in the short-term, adequate
numbers snags and down logs will be retained across the landscape.
In post-fire foraging (PFF) habitats, temporal bounding reflects effects of proposed activities to
snags compared to the natural decline in snag presence. In Idaho the half-life of snags in post-fire
areas where salvage logging did not occur was 9-10 years for ponderosa pine, and 15-16 years for
Douglas-fir (Russell et al. 2006). Using these estimates, if no action is taken, less than 10% of the
Douglas-fir snags will still be standing 60 years after the fires, and less than 2% of the ponderosa
pines will still be standing. The difference in habitat functionality of snags for NSO in PFF
habitats between the proposed activities and the no-action alternative is therefore not likely to be
meaningful at that point in time. In addition, there is considerable doubt as to the length of time
these habitats will be used by NSO into the future, and NSO use may well decline significantly or
discontinue in that time frame regardless of treatments. Down log density in these habitats is
expected to be high in either case due to significant additional tree mortality in the future from the
effects of the 2015 fires. As a result of these factors, a time scale of approximately 40 years
beyond implementation (60 years post-fire) is be used to bound the NSO cumulative effects
analysis.
The 35-year analysis period mentioned by the commenter was an error and will be corrected. The
cumulative effects bounding in the wildlife reports will be corrected to reflect this bounding.
The wildlife analysis discloses the rationale for determining which activities may cause
cumulative effects to NSO. For projects included in the cumulative effects analysis that treat
plantations, we assessed the conditions of those plantations to determine whether they include
suitable NSO habitat. Site visits were conducted to assess conditions in the oldest and most
developed plantations. These visits determined that NSO habitat was not present due to the
relatively young age of these plantations and the slow growth rate in this area. Grazing will affect
forbs and grasses, but is not expected to affect components of NSO habitats in any way that
would affect the suitability of these habitats to support NSO populations. The potential for
disturbance to NSO to result from these activities will be assessed when the cumulative effects
analysis is revised for the FEIS to incorporate new information now available.
Table 8 in the BA assesses cumulative effects from the Preferred Alternative to NSO under ESA.
Other wildlife reports assess cumulative effects under NEPA. Updated information on foreseeable
activities will be added to the wildlife analysis, and the analysis of cumulative effects in the BA
as well as other wildlife reports and the EIS will all be revised (including EIS Table 3-29) and the
FEIS will reflect this new information. These reports will also be reviewed to ensure consistency
574

Final Environmental Impact Statement

and completeness. The BA explains the methodology used to estimate which private lands were
likely to be harvested post-fire, and which were not. Because spatial data for post-fire harvesting
is now available, this information will be used to revise the cumulative effects analysis and that
analysis will be included in the FEIS.
NSO's are likely to be affected to some extent by direct effects to habitat from illegal marijuana
growing, and bioaccumulation of rodenticides. Regarding direct effects to habitat, habitat
mapping reflects the best available scientific information regarding current conditions. However,
marijuana cultivation on NFS lands is an illegal activity and conducted in secret, so the Forest is
not able to identify the location of these activities in a way that is sufficient to quantify effects to
individual NSO territories. In Trinity County, cultivation on NFS lands is typically small in scale,
and affects the understory rather than the overstory (to avoid aerial detection). Impacts of
cultivation on NSO habitat are thus much more limited than would be the case if the overstory
was being removed. Actions on private lands related to marijuana cultivation are either included
in a THP or THP exemption that will be updated in the FEIS, or are illegal and cannot be spatially
quantified. Regarding rodenticides, the California Department of Fish and Wildlife (CDFW,
2016) addressed potential effects on NSO from bioaccumulation of rodenticides. Although these
compounds have been recorded in a small number of NSO's in California, there is little data
available on their impacts on this species. Studies on other raptors indicate lethal and sublethal
impacts of anticoagulant rodenticides exposure, and raptors comprise two-thirds of the
anticoagulant-related wildlife mortalities documented by CDFW. CDFW concluded that it is
likely that rodenticides pose a "serious and widespread" threat to NSO's. "The extent of exposure
to Northern Spotted Owls and impacts on overall owl fitness (e.g., survival and fecundity)
remains unknown and is in need of further research." Impacts of rodenticides are thus potentially
serious, but impacts to individual NSO's in the analysis area for this project are impossible to
quantify. However, the proposed activities do not include use of rodenticides, and there is no
basis on which to conclude that the proposed activities would have any effect on bioaccumulation
of rodenticides in NSO's.

Comment: "Other scientists agree that wildfires are becoming more and more threatening and
severe, thus requiring action. But, due to the ineffectiveness of how fire managers are reducing
fuels in such ecosystems, just how that action becomes implemented is called into question
(LaHayne 2005).
The consensus seems to orbit around the theme that prudent management objectives are essential.
However, simply just saying that fire hazards need to be reduced and prescribed fire or salvage
logging are ways to achieve these objectives is not meeting the intentions outlined in numerous
studies and through empirical data. (Fire Science Brief - attached)."
Response: Each alternative is designed to meet the Purpose and Need. The purpose of this project
is to mitigate hazards that threaten public safety along open national forest system, county, and
state roads, sustain and establish forest cover, and capture economic value and support the
economics of local communities by providing forest products (DEIS, pg. 4). This project is not
designed to address how wildfires occur across the landscape but, over time, is expected to
influence how wildfires might impact the roads being treated in this project. LaHayne 2005 "The
Spotted Owl in Southern California: Ecology and Special Concerns for Maintaining a ForestDwelling Species in a Human-Dominated Desert Landscape" is specifically talking about changes
in fire regimes and using landscape fuels treatments to mitigate stand replacement fires and the
difficulty of treatments with public concern over air quality, safety, and liability. This project is
not designed as a landscape-scale project to restore historic fire regimes. Rather it is limited in
scope to meet the Purpose and Need-- while the treatments will trend the treated area closer to
historic fuels conditions, the project alternatives are designed primarily to meet the need of
reducing hazards along public roads in the burned area. Within our project area the fire regimes
haven't changed, and the proposed treatment size and locations are limited in scope to meet the
Purpose and Need.
The Paper, Fire Science Brief: "Burned Landscapes of Southwestern Oregon: What's In It for
Northern Spotted Owls?" suggests that outside of large-scale stand-replacing events, wildfire is
not likely a major threat to the persistence of spotted owls in this forest type—even though there
are numerous negative short term impacts. Results indicate that low-severity prescribed fire may
be used to help reduce fire hazard in dry forest ecosystems occupied by spotted owls. This paper
provides the first concrete guidelines for fuels reduction in spotted owl territories in southwestern
Oregon. The project is treating approximately 5% of the fire area along system roads for safety.
Low severity prescribed fire is outside the scope of our project. Our treatments are linear
treatments to reduce hazard trees and fuel loadings along open roads. It may be possible to
incorporate the treated area from this project into a future project within the fire area to
reintroduce low severity prescribed fire for NSO benefit.

Response: The significant threat that barred owls pose to NSOs is well documented in the BA.
The BA does not state that "the presence of barred owls and the impacts to NSO habitat will not
cause further intrusion by barred owls". It instead states that "there is no basis on which to
conclude that proposed activities will confer a significant competitive advantage to barred owls
over NSOs." This is based on the best available science on the effects of barred owls on NSO
(USDI Fish and Wildlife Service 2011 and others), and on the analysis on pp. 52-53 of the BA:
The proposed project is consistent with the NSO Revised Recovery Plan (USDI Fish and Wildlife
Service 2011), as detailed in Appendix 1 of the BA (pp. 95-96). It is unclear what information the
commenter is referring to regarding RA-10 consistency. Table 8 does not address this issue. Table
7 includes this information, but all 92 territories are included, with 52 designated as high-value
(RA-10) and 40 not designated as such. The rationale for each of these determinations is included
in Table 7."NSO habitat is well-distributed in the project area, and no NSO nesting/roosting,
foraging or dispersal habitats will be downgraded as a result of project activities. Only PFF areas
will be removed. The benefits of PFF areas to NSO, especially long-term benefits, are highly
uncertain. These areas are also much more limited in extent within treatment units than are
nesting/roosting, foraging or dispersal habitats. As a result, competitive or negative interactions
between barred owls and spotted owls are unlikely to significantly increase as a result of
implementing the proposed treatments, and there is no basis on which to conclude that proposed
activities will confer a significant competitive advantage to barred owls over NSOs In the longterm, treatments will benefit NSOs in relation to barred owls because the proposed treatments are
intended to accelerate the re-establishment of late-seral forest habitats highly suitable to NSOs
(Projects Wildlife BA p.55 & 87) and reduce fuels accumulations that would put high quality
NSO habitat at risk during another high severity wildfire.
The conclusion that predation does not pose a significant threat to NSOs is supported by the
barred owl analysis in the NSO Revised Recovery Plan (USDI Fish and Wildlife Service 2011).
"The BA on page 22 states the following related to predation: "Known predators of spotted owls
are limited to great horned owls (Forsman et al. 1984) and possibly barred owls (Wiens 2012,
Leskiw and Gutiérrez 1998). Hybridization between spotted owls and barred owls is also known
to occur (Kelly and Forsman 2004). Other suspected predators include northern goshawks, redtailed hawks, and other raptors (Courtney et al. 2004). Other sources of spotted owl mortality
include mammalian predation, starvation, and accidents (Forsman et al. 1984; Forsman et al.
2002). Mortality of juvenile spotted owls during dispersal is a major cause of poor recruitment
and declining population trends, and is assumed to be heightened by very open areas, including
some recently logged forest areas. These forest types support great horned owls. This species, and
the northern goshawk and red-tailed hawk, are all common throughout the South Fork and Trinity
River Management Units, and all are potential predators of spotted owls. Protocol surveys for
barred owls have not been conducted in the action area, but this species has been documented in
and near treatment units. Occasional predation of spotted owls by these raptors is not considered
to be a serious threat to spotted owl populations (USDI Fish and Wildlife Service 2011)."

Comment: "The DEIS states the 2001 Roadless Rule permits removal of timber from roadless

Final Environmental Impact Statement

fire. The FS should not be suppressing fire in roadless areas and natural processes should be
allowed to occur as in wilderness areas. While the FS may be able to remove some trees under
certain circumstances in roadless areas, we don't believe the case has been made to do so in this
project. Furthermore, the DEIS and IRA Report simply claim roadless characteristics will not be

the project if implemented will likely result in further intrusions by off road motorized vehicles.
View sheds will be altered and species that rely on early seral habitat will be affected.
The FS has not taken the requisite ""hard look"" required under NEPA for entering the six
inventoried roadless areas. Roadless areas serve as biological strongholds and refuges for many
species. Roadless areas support a diversity of aquatic habitats and communities providing or
affecting habitat for more than 280 TES species. The LRMP also states IRAs will be used as
habitat for TES species. Considering the significant impacts to NSO and critical habitat, the
project could have at least stayed out of the IRAs, instead it proposes to log 226 acres."
Response: The Forest values roadless characteristics on federal lands and aims to protect,
maintain, and improve those characteristics. The purpose of this project is to mitigate hazards (i.e.
fire-killed or defective trees and excessive fuels) that threaten public safety along open roads;
sustain and establish forest cover; and capture economic value and support the economies of local
communities by providing forest products. In order to achieve that goal, the Forest designed the
proposed action for this project specifically to address safety and future fuel loading issues and to
minimize impacts to roadless characteristics. Additionally, Alternative 5 was developed, in part,
to address concerns regarding logging activities within the inventoried roadless areas (IRAs). The
DEIS outlines two of the exemptions that are allowed for forest management activities within
IRAs. Both will be utilized for this project. The exemption for the removal of hazard trees and
fireline construction is described in 36 CFR 294.13(b)(2) (2001). This exemption will be applied
in all treatment areas to fell hazard trees of any size and if needed to create adequate control
features for prescribed fire activities. The exemption for the removal of ladder fuels and other
small diameter material to reduce the risk of uncharacteristic wildfire effects is described in 36
CFR 294.13(b)(1)(ii) (2001). This exemption will be applied to remove small diameter material
in order to meet fuels reduction objectives. For Alternatives 1 and 4 only dead trees would be cut
and for Alternatives 2 and 3 trees that had 60% or greater risk of mortality or were already dead
could be felled.
The commenter's statement that Maintenance Level 2 ('class 2') Roads are not open to passenger
cars is incorrect. While these roads are typically not suitable for passenger cars, passenger cars
are not prohibited from these roads and such cars often do use Maintenance Level 2 roads.
Management of IRAs is guided by the 2001 Roadless Rule which describes nine values that often
characterize IRAs. These were used as the basis for the IRA effects analysis. Each of the values
was considered for each of the IRAs independently and together to determine the impact of
proposed activities on roadless characteristics. The type and extent of activities proposed for each
Alternative within each IRA were identified. These activities were then assessed for their impact
to each roadless area individually and collectively. The comment specifically identifies the
following concerns: impacts to viewsheds, early seral habitat, and off-highway (OHV) vehicle
intrusions. Impacts to the viewsheds are assessed in the primitive, semi-primitive non-motorized
and semi-primitive motorized classes of dispersed recreation; and natural appearing landscapes
with high scenic quality sections of the IRA analysis (DEIS pgs. 330-332). A majority of the
proposed treatment areas have a visual quality objective of modification which allows for
evidence of management on the landscape.
Early seral habitat is not one of the nine characteristics of inventoried roadless areas. The IRA
effects analysis did consider threatened, endangered, and sensitive species that may be impacted
by treatments. Some of these species may be associated with early seral habitat, however it is not
anticipated that the project would have negative effects on these species (DEIS, pg. 329).
Additionally the IRA analysis considered the diversity of plant and animal communities within
50T

50T

580

Final Environmental Impact Statement

Trinity Post Fire Hazard Reduction and Salvage

IRAs (DEIS, pg. 328). The focus of this analysis was on the introduction of noxious weeds into
the post-fire and post-treatment environment. A general estimate of early seral habitat created
from the 2015 fires is described in the vegetation existing condition narrative (DEIS, pg. 77).
Approximately 33,920 acres burned at high to moderate severity resulting in at least 25% canopy
mortality. Only 11,000 acres of that deforested area would be planted as a result of this project
and the 2015 Fire Reforestation Project (DEIS, pg. 86). This will leave over 22,000 acres of
newly created early seral habitat on the landscape. After fires, OHV trespass is often concentrated
around dozer lines and other areas that had been cleared during fire suppression efforts. OHV
trespass through roadside forest management treatments into adjacent general forest or protected
areas has not been a significant issue on the Shasta-Trinity (E-Mail from Lisa Walker, OHV
Coordinator 5/12/2017). It is not anticipated that the proposed treatments will increase OHV
intrusions above existing background levels. Finally, note that the 226 acres of treatment
proposed in the preferred alternative represents less than 0.5% of the total area (84,934) of the
IRAs impacted by the 2015 fires and is located along areas that are already fragmented and
disturbed due to the existing road system.

require the direct survey of Sensitive species (individuals as opposed to their habitat) as a class.

analyzed in the Botanical and Wildlife Biological Evaluations. Where suitable habitat exists for a
particular Forest Service Sensitive species, occupation was assumed, impacts from the proposed
project were analyzed, and the appropriate conservation measures were applied. Therefore the
Forest has made a concerted effort to conserve and protect Forest Service Sensitive Species so as
not to contribute to future listing.

45. C onservation Congress - Denise Boggs
50T

Comment: “The BA states a circle radius of 5 miles encompasses the average territory size for
gray wolves and the project is outside the known range of the species and therefore will have no
effects on the species. This is incorrect not to mention absurd. According to the MT Dept. of Fish,
Wildlife & Parks: Some Gray Wolves are known to have dispersed up to 805 km (500 miles).
Dispersal has been documented from Canada, Idaho and Wyoming to Montana. Montana Gray
Wolves are also known to have dispersed to Canada, Idaho, and Wyoming. Average territory size
in northwestern Montana was 220 square kilometers (185 square miles) but was highly variable
(USFWS et al. 2002). Average territory size for Yellowstone Gray Wolves was larger, averaging
891 square kilometers (344 square miles) (USFWS et al. 2002).
According to International Wolf Center: Territory size is highly variable and depends on a number
of factors such as prey abundance, the nature of the terrain, climate and the presence of other
predators including other wolf packs. Gray wolf territories in the lower 48 states may be less than
100 square miles while territories in Alaska and Canada can range from about 300 to 1,000 square
miles or more. Red wolf territories in northeastern North Carolina vary in size, but most are
estimated to range between 38 to 87 square miles.
Considering an entire pack of wolves was documented living on the McCloud District of the
Shasta-Trinity NF, gray wolves could easily be on the Trinity side of the Forest and in the project
area.
Gray Wolves need to be analyzed in the BA and the STNF should consult with the FWS on this
species."
Response: As is the case with migratory bird routes spanning from one continent to another,
dispersal paths are not typically considered part of an animal's home range. Including dispersal
paths would result in home range estimates that would be inaccurate and misleading. The analysis
in the BA was developed in coordination with the US Fish and Wildlife Service. Gray wolves
inhabit a wide variety of habitats across their very large species range, and home range size
estimates are correspondingly extremely variable, typically ranging from 20-400 square miles,
varying year-to-year, and tending to be smaller in lower latitudes (Mech and Boitani 2003; Fuller
et al. 2003; USDI Fish and Wildlife Service 2013; Wiles et al. 2011; Oregon Department of Fish
and Wildlife 2010). A 400 square mile territory is equivalent to a circle with radius 11.3 miles.
The nearest known wolf site is located 70-90 miles away from the project area. Therefore this
project will have no effect on wolves or on its critical habitat. The wolf analysis will be updated
to incorporate recent information from the US Fish and Wildlife Service and other sources.

Comment: “The DEIS states post-treatment total soil cover should be between 50 and 70%
averaged across the treatment area on metamorphics with at least 50% cover as fine organic
matter. The FS didn't include an LRMP cite for this direction (as it did for many other statements

across the treatment area. In addition, in areas that burned at high intensity and have lost soil
cover, the FS proposes that soil will be retained to the extent practicable. The FS is required to
use the best available scientific information and we aren't aware of any suggesting logging in
areas with no soil cover is good for the soil or the forest. Indeed, we sent a bibliography to the
STNF including dozens of papers discouraging salvage logging because it is does far more harm
to forest resources than leaving burned forest intact. The STNF ignored all of the scientific
information we provided, so we are including it again with these comments.
Response: The Shasta-Trinity LRMP Standards and Guidelines, chapter 4 section 18 Soils and
Water subsection d, e, and j and Appendix O was used to address soil cover. "Areas of detrimental
soil disturbance that affect soil productivity, should not be of a size or extent that would result in a
significant change in production potential for the activity area." Activity Area is "that area of land
to which soil productivity soil quality standards are applied. It is that area within a management
area where soil disturbing activities take place. It is of a practical size for management, sampling
and evaluation. Activity areas include timber harvest units within a sale area, burn areas within a
prescribed burn, and grazing areas within an allotment. System roads and trails and other
dedicated areas are not considered activity areas.”
Based on your comment, we recognize that there may have been some confusion regarding the
Resource Protection Measure that you cited. In order to clarify our actions and to ensure
consistency with Appendix O of the LRMP, we will change the text of the Resource Protection
Measure (#46 in DEIS) from “treatment area” to “activity area”. See Physical Science report page
26, "Across all fires, there was an average of 28% moderate to high soil burn severity and 72%
low to very low soil burn severity. In areas where soils were burned at moderate to high intensity,
soil structure was destroyed, soil cover was removed, and water repellency was common. Since
the highly burned landscapes (where most of the salvage will occur) lack cover, returning as
much cover as possible during implementation is desirable.” This technique was used recently for
the Stafford Fire Salvage Project of 2013 (Rust, 2015). On that project, cover was maximized as
much as possible in areas that burned hot and soil cover was marginal. Techniques of lop-andscatter and mastication of dead un-merchantable material was utilized to return cover to the
ground and slow erosion. Immediate cover was needed to protect severely burned soils from
50T

50T

50T

584

Final Environmental Impact Statement

Trinity Post Fire Hazard Reduction and Salvage

accelerated erosion and the loss of important nutrients that are held in the duff and organic matter
in the surface horizons. Additionally, salvage breaks up water repellant surface layers and
provides a surface roughness factor that reduces erosion (James, C., 2013). In short, salvage
harvest can increase soil cover and reduce water repellency, especially within areas that burned at
high intensity. These techniques were evaluated by Busse et. al. 2014, James et. al. 2014, and
MacDonald et. al. (2015).The basis for the 50-70% soil cover is from forest service research.
"Litter and duff occurs over at least 50 percent of the activity area. Determine minimum organic
layer thickness locally and base it on an amount sufficient to persist through winter season storms
and summer season oxidation" SHF LRMP Appendix O, page O1 under surface organic matter.
Appendix O goes on to say "Use the presence of living vegetation that could contribute
significant annual litter fall to compensate for conditions when immediate post disturbance litter
and duff coverage is too thin or less than 50 percent. If the soil and potential natural plant
community are not capable of producing cover over 50 percent of the area, adjust minimum
amounts to reflect potential soil and vegetation capability". Finally, the project is not expected to
result in a significant change in productivity across any of the harvest units.

50T

Comment: “The STNF used an assessment developed in 1983 (34 years ago) for its ERA model.
It is assumed that salvage logging in moderate to high severity burned areas will be
approximately a clearcut, and salvage logging in unburned to low severity burned areas will be
approximately a thin. (We note here that none of the wildlife reports produced for this project
considers salvage logging in moderate to high severity burn as a clearcut - but we agree). Using
the 34 year old model, the DEIS states the rate of recovery is dependent upon the recovery
coefficient. For example, for mechanical piling and burning the disturbed area will recover by
22% after three years and by about 68% after 30 years. The ERA was calculated using the model,
and converted to a total in tons based on an estimated 13.6 tons/road mile calculated from the
WEPP model. It was assumed that about 30% of the total sediment produced would eventually
enter a stream. The DEIS continues that even approximately predicting the amount of sediment at
the watershed scale is difficult to determine due to numerous variables and therefore the results
should be viewed as best guess approximations of the amount of sediment that may reach the
streams, rather than accurate forecasts of what we know will happen.”
Response: The Forest used an assessment developed in 1983 (34 years ago) for its equivalent
roaded area (ERA) model. The Forest Service Region 5 FSH 2509.22 Soil and Water
Conservation Handbook, chapter 20, requires the use of the ERA model. Although development
of the ERA model used by the Forest began with Haskins (1983), the model can be refined and
modified over time. When the modeling for this project was initially done, the Forest did not have
a salvage logging activity built into the model. It was assumed that salvage logging in moderate
to high severity burned areas would be approximately a clearcut because a clearcut was the
50T

50T

585

Final Environmental Impact Statement

Trinity Post Fire Hazard Reduction and Salvage

closest available activity built into the model at the time. Since then however, the Forest has
added salvage logging activities for high and moderate burn severity areas into the model.
Salvage logging in moderate to high severity burned areas will be modeled as approximately
equivalent to removing the negative effects of the fire (due to the activities breaking up the
hydrophobicity of the soils) and doing a clearcut (highest level of impacts assumed).The term
clearcut is generally applied to "green tree" harvests, which are not proposed in this project. The
wildlife reports instead assess the effects of proposed activities on habitat quality for NSO and
other wildlife species, including the effects of hazard tree abatement and commercial salvage
(highest level of impacts assumed).

50. C onservation Congress - Denise Boggs
50T

Comment: To make the ""analysis"" even more meaningless the CWE were analyzed by
estimating the ERA within each hydrologic unit (HUC 5 to 8) and the results were compared
against the TOC established for each watershed that range from 12 to 18% ERA (Appendix H of
USDA FS, 1995b). Effects of the wildfire 2015 wildfires, fire suppression, and proposed project
activities are forecast for a 5-year period - despite the fact the DEIS claims the project may take
up to 20 years to implement. The analysis lists other projects including private lands logging.
After using a 34 year old model to determine ERA and then estimating the ERA and comparing
them against the TOC established in 1995 (22 years ago), the conclusions are that baseline
disturbance of the affected watersheds is low to moderate. Imagine what they would be if a real
analysis was conducted using scientifically updated models and accurate survey information?
Again, the STNF seems to think that producing a DEIS allows it to harm any resource, and
acknowledging harm using shoddy information, as long as it says harm will occur. That is not the
way the law works. Considering some of these watersheds are listed as impaired under the EPA
the FS has a responsibility to meet EPA standards."
Response: Development of the ERA model used by the Forest began 34 years ago with Haskins
(1983), but the model can be modified or refined at any time (Forest Service Region 5 FSH
2509.22 Soil and Water Conservation Handbook chapter 20, page 3). The Forest recently updated
the model to include salvage logging (see detailed explanation in the Hydrology Report).
Additional activities can be added at any time in the future, or the coefficients of activities can be
modified at any time if new information is available. Anyone is welcome to submit accurate
scientific information to us at any time, and we will consider it and, if scientifically appropriate,
use it to further update the model. Cumulative watershed effects were analyzed by estimating the
equivalent roaded area (ERA) because the Forest Service Region 5 FSH 2509.22 Soil and Water
Conservation Handbook chapter 10 (page 41) requires that the Forest Service assess and consider
the potential for cumulative watershed effects of proposed activities, and it states that the
approach uses the ERA model. Fifth-field through eighth-field hydrologic units were analyzed
within the EIS. The Forest Plan (page 4-25) requires that watersheds identified in the final EIS
(standard and guideline 18.b) and watersheds averaging about 1,000 acres in size (standard and
guideline 18.a) are to be analyzed. Watersheds identified in the final EIS are equivalent to 5thfield and/or 6th-field watersheds. Eighth-field watersheds are approximately 1000 acres in size.
Fifth-field and seventh-field hydrologic units are needed for the environmental baseline analyses
conducted by the fisheries biologists. The ERA results are required to be compared to the
Threshold of Concern (TOC) to comply with the Forest Plan. Standard and Guideline 18a(3) on
page 4-25 states that projects on National Forest System lands should not increase the ERA above
the proportional share of the TOC unless, as part of the project, existing ERAs will be reduced or
the ERA recovery factor will be improved.
There is no schedule of implementation for how the proposed activities will take place in each
watershed, so it is assumed in the model that the activities will occur within the first year that the
Record of Decision will be signed. This assumption is a worst case scenario because the
cumulative effects will be worse if the activities are implemented simultaneously rather than
implemented gradually over time. The duration of the analysis is from 2018 to 2022. The
50T

50T

50T

potential for indirect effects is reduced over time and is often not evident 5 years after project
implementation. There are no foreseeable future projects beyond 2019. Although a watershed
may take more than 5 years to recover from cumulative effects, it is expected that significant long
term, potentially chronic effects, will be present only in watersheds over TOC. The South Fork
Trinity River sub-basin is included on California's Clean Water Act Section 303(d) list as water
quality limited due to sediment and temperature, and part of the Trinity River sub-basin is 303(d)

addresses nonpoint source discharges of waste to waters of the state from activities associated
with specific uses of NFS lands. The Shasta Trinity National Forest will comply with the Waiver.
