50T

Comment: “Under desired condition the DEIS states ACS objectives provide direction for
watershed management on the STNF and the objectives were developed to maintain and restore
the ecological health of the aquatic ecosystem of the forest. The compliance document found in
Appendix E describes the objectives. Appendix E states for each objective generally: project
implementation via any of the action alternatives will maintain attainment of the objective at the
watershed and project site scale (aided greatly by Project EEZs, BMPs, and RPMs.) This despite
the analysis being based on best guesses, outdated models, and the admission the BMPs and
RPMs may not work in all places. Forgive us for not believing the hydrology and ACSO
determinations.”
Response: The Aquatic Conservation Strategy (ACS) was developed to restore and maintain
aquatic ecosystems to further the ecological health of the watersheds that contain them. A key
driver is protecting salmon and steelhead habitat on Forest Service lands. One of the tactics to
achieve the goal is maintaining the natural disturbance regime. Complying with the ACS means
that the Shasta Trinity National Forest (Forest) must manage riparian-dependent resources to
maintain the existing condition or if logical, restore conditions to fit within natural disturbance
regimes. The proposed action honors the guidelines of the ACS that specifically mention 1)
avoiding areas prone to instability, 2) minimizing increases in peak streamflows, in this case by
treating legacy roads and controlling surface runoff, and 3) protecting riparian areas along
channels to limit bank erosion while promoting shade and coarse woody debris accumulation as
accomplished through equipment exclusion zones (EEZs). Resource Protection Measures (RPMs)
include Best Management Practices (BMPs) such as EEZs. Generally, the models the Forest uses
are considered the best available science. The Equivalent Roaded Area (ERA) model that we are
required to use (R5 FSH 2509.22 Chapter 10) for assessing cumulative watershed effects has
been in use for three decades, but the data compiled for these assessments is updated frequently
with past, present and reasonably foreseeable future activities. The compilation of this data is
itself a comprehensive look at cumulative effects. We also used the Water Erosion Prediction
Project (WEPP) model to estimate rates of erosion. Although we are not required to use WEPP,
the Forest Service does consider it to be a scientifically valid model (R5 FSH 2509.22 Chapter
10). A reasonable time frame for goal achievement is also required as per the ACS language
itself: "Because (the ACS) is based on natural disturbance processes, it may take decades,
possibly more than a century, to accomplish all of its objectives. Some improvements in aquatic
ecosystems, however, can be expected in 10 to 20 years". The effect of treatments from the
various action alternatives in relation to the nine objectives of the ACS are clearly and fully
described in the table referred to in this particular comment, found in the fish biological
evaluation, specialist and management indicator species report, and Table E-1 of the DEIS.

50T

Comment: “We don't consider a likely to adversely affect critical habitat determination as
"some" changes. What the DEIS fails to state is that the NSO may very well be extinct by the
time the habitat recovers and any NSO in the project area require that habitat NOW. The DEIS
and supporting documents also fail to state the FWS is considering uplisting the NSO to
endangered status and that determination should be forthcoming any day now. The DEIS
downplays impacts to owl habitat and states impacts will last for up to 35 years or 60 years or
some other arbitrary number. Considering nesting/roosting habitat is generally old growth habitat
which takes 180-220 years to develop, the time frames in the analyses are not accurate.”
Response: Effects to NSO were fully disclosed and analyzed in the project BA, as required by
the ESA, and a determination of "may affect, likely to adversely affect" was reached. If the listing
status of NSO under ESA changes, the need to re-initiate consultation will be assessed at that
time. Temporal bounding of effects was established by considering the specific actions proposed
and the expected time for re-establishment of habitat functions. Proposed activities in the
Preferred Alternative which was analyzed in the BA are limited to dead vegetation (cutting of
dying vegetation is included in Alternatives 2 and 3), and effects to suitable NSO habitats are
expected to be more limited in intensity and duration than green tree treatments. Actions such as
clearcutting stands of old-growth habitat are not proposed, and in fact the project does not
propose any downgrade or removal of nesting and roosting habitat, so the time frame cited in the
comment is not applicable in this case. Temporal bounding for this analysis is both short term and
long term. The short-term bounding is the time during project implementation because it is tied
directly to the potential for noise disturbance and immediate habitat alteration. The estimated
timeline for hazard tree abatement, fuel loading reduction, wood product removal and planting
implementation is up to 5 years, and maintenance actions may occur up to 20 years into the
future.
Long-term bounding is determined by several factors. First, we looked at the habitat elements for
NSO and determined that snag density and down logs were the elements that would be affected
by the project for greatest amount of time. Then, we determined that the effects of this project on
snags and down logs would not be meaningful approximately 40 years after implementation (60
years post-fire). In current NSO nesting/roosting, foraging and dispersal habitats, the reduction in
snag numbers due to this project will be counteracted within 60 years through ongoing mortality,
including additional tree mortality from the effects of the 2015 fires. This tree mortality is also
expected to provide a high density of down logs in these habitats. This bounding is used to fully
account for any type of impacts although it exaggerates the reduction of snags and down logs due
to the narrow treatment area along open roads. Note that even in the short-term, adequate
numbers snags and down logs will be retained across the landscape.

55. C onservation Congress - Denise Boggs
50T

Comment: Plantations aren't even considered developed until 80 years and this project will result
in clearcuts of snag habitat.
Response: Plantations aren't considered to have achieved late successional characteristics until at
least 80 years, but they are considered developed once they are established and start contributing
canopy cover, approximately 5-20 years following planting. Often, they are developed to the
extent that thinning can be accomplished under a commercial harvest at 40 years. This project
mitigates hazards in areas impacted from the 2015 fires along roads. Areas that experienced
moderate to high fire severity have more hazards and therefore will result in a greater number of
snags treated (whether by falling, treating fuels in place, or removal). Note that the approximately
136,000 acres affected by the fire and not included in this project (90-95% of the fire affected
area, depending on Alternative) will have no impact on snag habitat.

61. Wild Nature Institute - Monica Bond
50T

Comment: "Thank you for the opportunity to provide comments on the Trinity Post-Fire Hazard
Reduction and Salvage Project. I am a wildlife biologist with experience in the study of
California spotted owls in post-fire landscapes. I have published peer-reviewed scientific papers
that cover a range of issues from territory occupancy rates, home range sizes, and diets in postfire landscapes and post-fire habitat selection. I have also visited portions of the Trinity Project
area. Here I provide comments on the Wildlife Biological Assessment (hereafter ""assessment"")
with respect to the Northern Spotted Owl (NSO).
Designated NSO critical habitat makes up 55% of the 8,000 acre-area of potential logging
(although the proposed acreage may overestimate the actual acreage to be logged), with 7 NSO
territories affected. The NSO is declining throughout its range, therefore the effects of logging in
this project are not insignificant to the population. The analyses in the assessment is based on
scientifically unjustified assumptions, such as a 500-foot buffer into burned forests."
Response: The NSO's current status, population trends and primary threats are discussed in the
BA and considered in the analysis. The project has been specifically designed to minimize
potential effects to NSO while allowing for the Purpose and Need to be met. The determination
for both effects to NSO and to NSO Critical Habitat is "may affect, likely to adversely affect"
50T

50T

50T

590

Final Environmental Impact Statement

Trinity Post Fire Hazard Reduction and Salvage

because the effects of the project may rise above the level of insignificant, discountable, and
instead have a significant effect on NSO and/or NSO Critical Habitat. This is disclosed and
analyzed in the BA. The 500-foot buffer around burned habitat is an estimate of the distance from
suitable NSO nesting/roosting or foraging habitat that NSOs are likely to go to forage in post-fire
foraging areas. The process used to arrive at this distance is detailed in the section of the BA
entitled "Assessing Post-Fire NSO Habitat Suitability." In the absence of recommendations
specific to the question of how far from the edge of surviving nesting/roosting or foraging
habitats NSO are most likely to fly into burned areas (post-fire foraging habitats), the Yreka FWS
Office and Forest discussed the questions at length and reached a consensus. The distance NSO
are assumed most likely to forage away from the protective overhead cover provided by
nesting/roosting or foraging habitats is estimated to be approximately 500 feet. This estimate was
derived from a review of recent literature on the use of edge habitat (Comfort 2013; Eyes 2014),
professional judgment based on the biology of northern spotted owls, and extensive field
observations of NSO on the Shasta-Trinity National Forest (Rogers et al. pers. comm.). As a
result, these habitats (PFF1 habitats) within High-Value Wildlife Conservation Areas receive
enhanced resource protection measures regardless of their distance from an NSO activity center.
This does not imply that no NSO foraging will occur beyond this distance, but is simply a
determination that foraging is much less likely beyond this distance.

62. Wild Nature Institute - Monica Bond
50T

Comment: First, I want to commend the Forest Service for designating post-fire foraging type 1
(PFF1) areas for NSOs. This is a critical first step towards acknowledging the importance of postfire forests as foraging habitat for NSOs and a host of other native species. Post-fire foraging type
1 areas are NSO nesting/roosting/foraging habitats that were affected by higher-severity fire and
within 500 feet of currently suitable NRF habitats. I appreciate that the ecological value of these
areas is being accepted. However, the best available science suggests that post-fire foraging areas
extend to within 2.2 km of spotted owl territories. Clark et al. (2013) states in Management
Implications that "we recommend restricting salvage logging after fires on public lands within 2.2
km of spotted owl territories (the median home range size in this portion of the spotted owl's
range) to limit the negative impacts of salvage logging." Foraging California spotted owls have
been observed selecting for severe fire forest patches up to 1.5 km from their nest sites (Bond et
al. 2009). Therefore, 500 feet is an insufficient buffer, and is not scientifically justified in the
literature, or in the assessment. NSO have large home ranges, and areas farther from the nest core
may be important for NSO during the non-breeding season as these raptors expand their areas of
use as they deplete their prey base during the breeding season (Carey et al. 1992). I had
previously noted this fundamental flaw in my comments to the Forest Service on the Draft
Environmental Impact Statement, Biological Assessment, and Biological Evaluation for the
Westside 'Fire Recovery' project (see my attached comments from Westside, page 4). I
recommend extending this PFF1 designation to 2.2 km for NSO, as recommended by the best
available science (Clark et al. 2013). This will provide greater certainty that harm is not inflicted
on this declining subspecies during harvesting for wood products. Detailed comments are
provided below.
Response: The analysis in the BA is based on a thorough review of the scientific literature on the
use of burned areas by spotted owls (California and Mexican spotted owls as well as northern
spotted owls). The analysis compares research results and recommendations to identify their
similarities and contrasts, as well as their strengths and weaknesses. Based on the assessment of
the best available science, the Forest worked closely with the US Fish and Wildlife Service to
minimize potential effects to NSO while still achieving the project's Purpose and Need. Research
utilized in this analysis and cited extensively includes works by Clark, and by the commenter
(Ms. Bond). Based on research conducted by the commenter and others, this analysis identifies
post-fire foraging (PFF) habitats as habitats utilized by spotted owls post-fire. Resource
protection measures for the proposed project provide additional protection for PFF habitats within
50T

50T

591

Final Environmental Impact Statement

Trinity Post Fire Hazard Reduction and Salvage

HVWCAs that are within 500 feet of existing nesting/roosting or foraging habitats. Potential
effects to PFF habitats are disclosed and analyzed throughout the BA, particularly on pp. 30-31
and 47-52.The 2.2 km figure in Clark et al. (2013) is a recommendation to protect burned habitats
on public lands within 2.2 km of California spotted owl activity centers. It is unclear why this
recommendation is restricted to public lands. The 500-foot figure in the analysis for the proposed
project is entirely different. It is an estimate of how far into burned areas NSO are most likely
willing to fly from the edge of suitable nesting/roosting or foraging habitats to forage in burned
(post-fire foraging) areas. This distance is independent of the distance from an NSO activity
center. As a result, these habitats (PFF1 habitats) within High-Value Wildlife Conservation Areas
receive enhanced resource protection measures regardless of their distance from an NSO activity
center. The 500-foot figure was determined in close coordination with the US Fish and Wildlife
Service. It reflects the best available scientific information on habitat use by NSO, extensive
observations of NSO behavior on the Shasta-Trinity National Forest, and the best scientific
judgement of US Forest Service and US Fish and Wildlife Service Wildlife Biologists (in the
absence of a consensus on this particular question in the published literature).

63. Wild Nature Institute - Monica Bond
50T

Comment: The purpose and need for action mentions that dead trees elevate future fire risk and
danger to firefighters, and wildfire suppression strategies would therefore be limited. However, I
question the underlying assumption that wildfire suppression in these remote forested areas is
even a necessary or laudable goal. Firefighting and management activities to reduce fire risk
should be focused on areas immediately surrounding towns and critical infrastructure such as
power lines. Limited funds would be better spent repeatedly removing vegetation within 100 feet
of homes and subsidizing homeowners to retrofit their houses to be less vulnerable to catching
fire. This is the only way to truly protect human communities from any damage from wildfire. In
the surrounding forests, fire is a natural component of ecological dynamics and indeed provides
important habitat for many native species. Finally, no amount of logging will reduce fire during
extreme weather events which burn most of the acreage. There are so many scientific references
supporting the need to focus on the area immediate surrounding homes, and that fire is
ecologically critical in western forests, and that logging does not reduce large fires, that I am
going to refer here to a recent book entitled Nature's Phoenix, edited by Della Salla and Hanson
2016, that summarizes very well these points and the hundreds of references that support them.
Contributors to the book include some of the world's foremost fire ecologists and experts.
Response: One element of the purpose of this project is to mitigate hazards (i.e. fire killed or
defective trees and excessive fuels) that threaten public safety along open National Forest System,
County, and State roads. This purpose stems from needs based on the Land and Resource
Management Plan for the Shasta-Trinity National Forests (USDA, 1995a) and the post-fire
assessment (See Purpose and Need, FEIS Chapter 1).The objectives and strategies for response to
future wildland fires on the Shasta-Trinity National Forest are outside the scope of this project.
However, managing fuels for public safety is a top priority for the Forest (Forest Plan 4-18).
Mitigating hazards along the roads identified in this project is expected to increase the likelihood
of safe ingress and egress both post-fire and in the event of future wildfires, of which logging
could be method for implementation. This is consistent with the management direction identified
in the need for this project. The Forest recognizes the value of making homes fire safe and
reducing fuels within 100 feet of structures; however, this project is concerned with creating safe
conditions for travel on roads through land managed by the Shasta-Trinity National Forest.
Additionally, portions of the project area are located within the wildland-urban interface, as
identified by the Shasta-Trinity National Forest and the Trinity County Community Wildfire
Protection Plan. The Forest recognizes that fire is an important ecological function. By reducing
excessive fuels to levels more consistent with a pre-fire-suppression fire regime, the project is
consistent with the Land and Resource Management Plan direction to restore and replicate fire's
role in the ecosystem (Forest Plan 4-4 & 4-16).

64. Wild Nature Institute - Monica Bond
50T

Comment: The purpose and need for the Trinity Project also purports a need to sustain and
establish forest cover. The best scientific data available have demonstrated that seedlings reestablish naturally in the absence of any post-fire management activities by people. Please see
Donato et al. (2006, 2009). Therefore, replanting is not necessary, and indeed logging operations
damage naturally regrowing seedlings that are locally genetically adapted for the area. The local
genetic adaptation of seedlings re-establishing after wildfire must be addressed as a significant
scientific issue in any analyses of effects of logging operations.
Response: While Donato's papers indicate natural regeneration is sufficient, it is not the only
literature related to post fire reforestation and does not follow any long term efficacy study.
Natural regeneration tends to be concentrated adjacent to unburned areas or those that retained
mature (live) trees following fire. Reforestation associated with this project will focus on larger
areas of moderate to high severity in the roadside buffer that are lacking in mature forest cover to
provide a sufficient seed source to establish conifer seedlings prior to shrub domination. Note that
additional post-fire reforestation efforts are on-going as indicated in the Cumulative Effects table,
and focus on areas of interior forest including productive natural stands greater than 10 acres and
plantations that were impacted by high to moderate severity wildfire. As disclosed in the
Vegetation section of Chapter 3, natural revegetation of the burned areas within the project area,
especially outside of treatment areas, will occur to a small degree over time, primarily with forbs
and shrubs; forested conditions in areas burned at high severity are unlikely to occur for 20-100
years. For the larger, high severity burned areas, reforestation will take a long period of time due,
in part, to the distance from seed sources as well as a potential decrease in soil
productivity/fertility. It is expected that hardwoods and shrubs will resprout vigorously
throughout the recovery area. After fire mortality has ceased, large areas in all land allocations
severely affected by the fires would be understocked or unstocked for forest development and
associated timber production for many decades (Clark 2009; Ouzts et al. 2015).While groundbased logging operations that occur after a couple seasons of seedling establishment may impact
natural regeneration, planting of a species mix consistent with historic conditions will be
implemented to ensure cover. Seeds propagated for planting under this project have been
collected within the local area (seed zone 312; Buck et al. 1970) and within an appropriate
elevational band to allow for the best chance for seedling health and survival.

65. Wild Nature Institute - Monica Bond
50T

Comment: “In essence, the science demonstrates that (1) wildfire created necessary and
important habitat for many western native species, (2) trees regrow naturally on their own without
human intervention, and (3) logging is not an effective means of reducing wildfire spread or
intensity during extreme weather conditions-which are the only conditions that might result in
large areas of high-severity wildfire that might reduce nesting and roosting habitats for NSO.
Therefore, the purpose and need for this project has not been scientifically justified.”
Response: This project or the analysis of this project does not dispute that wildfire creates
necessary and important habitat for many western native species or that trees regrow naturally on
their own without human intervention. The Purpose and Need was developed based on the social
and economic context of managing National Forest System lands following a fire. Infrastructure,
including roads, exists on the landscape for human use of the land and resources. This project was
designed with a narrow focus, to reduce hazards along roads open to the public that were
impacted by the 2015 wildfires on the Shasta-Trinity National Forest. The actions proposed under
each alternative were developed following law, regulation, and policy and use best available
science with varying approaches to meet the intent of the Purpose and Need. Under the preferred
alternative, 8,000 acres of roadside treatment is proposed out of approximately 144,000 acres of
NFS lands burned. The 95 percent of fire area outside of the proposed treatments still allow for
natural processes to occur, including providing habitat for native species. Post-fire habitat
features that remain potentially useful to some wildlife species, most notably fire-killed snags, are
593
50T

50T

Final Environmental Impact Statement

Trinity Post Fire Hazard Reduction and Salvage

abundant across the 95 percent of untreated burned areas and will remain so due to no treatment
in those areas. Timber harvest or removal of hazard trees in a narrow buffer along roads is one of
many tools utilized in this project design to reduce overall fuel levels to achieve the desired
conditions along open roads. The project is not designed to affect fire behavior across the
landscape, only directly adjacent to roads open to the public. Reforestation is proposed in high
severity areas because the seed source has been removed by the fire. Although the area could
potentially reforest naturally the timeframe that it might occur in and the potential for
revegetation by highly flammable brush species in the meantime would create a hazard to the
road. The effects that this project has on wildlife habitat, fire behavior, and vegetation under each
alternative are disclosed in the EIS.

66. Wild Nature Institute - Monica Bond
50T

Comment: “The Project Design Features indicate that trees will be cut that pose a hazard to roads
and/or logging operations. It is rather circular reasoning to state that trees will be cut that pose a
hazard to the cutting operation. Even if trees posing a hazard to operations or haul routes will be
cut and retained, that is the loss of a standing snag that could have provided a perch site for a
foraging NSO or a nest or roost site for a woodpecker or other fire-dependent native species. The
Forest Service has therefore not demonstrated a need to cut trees that pose a hazard to the treecutting operation that itself is largely unnecessary. I propose instead that only trees that are both
dead and leaning directly over a high-traffic road will be hand-cut, and all of those cut trees will
be retained on-site as logs. No other trees will be cut. This is the type of lower-impact "hazardreduction" design feature that would minimize the adverse effects on NSO and other wildlife
within HVWCAs, suitable NSO NRF habitat, and PFF1 areas. I suggest this option be analyzed
in a new EIS.”
Response: This RPM is included as a reflection of OSHA requirements. In Alternatives 1, 2, 3,
and 4, any trees cut because they pose a hazard to logging operations are limited only to those
posing a danger to the operators cutting the trees (per OSHA 29 CFR 1910.266). Further, fallers
would have no financial incentive to cut trees that are not an imminent hazard to them because
operational hazards that are not dead at the time of implementation or are felled outside of the
treatment buffer cannot be logged (sold and removed offsite). No additional trees will be cut
under this provision beyond those necessary to address the danger posed to operators. There are
seldom cases where a hazard to operators would not also be a hazard to the road, given the
relatively narrow buffers associated with this project. Reclassifying a narrow definition of hazard
tree inconsistent with accepted regulation and policy does not meet the Purpose and Need for
mitigating hazards that threaten public safety along open roads. In response to this comment the
Forest has considered another alternative (Alternative 11). The alternative would cut dead trees
that are overhanging ML 3-5 NFS, County, and State roads and leave them in place after falling.
This action would leave hazard trees and excessive fuels along open roads in the fire footprints.
This alternative is not consistent with OSHA regulations (29 CFR 1910.266(d)(6)(ii) and 29 CFR
1910.226(h)(1)) and Forest Service policy (FSH 6709.11 Health and Safety Code Handbook).
This alternative has been eliminated from detailed study because it does not meet the Purpose
and Need to mitigate hazards on open roads in areas burned during the 2015 fires. This comment
discounts that approximately 136,000 acres (using the proposed action footprint) impacted by the
2015 fires on Shasta-Trinity National Forest are not impacted by this project and would continue
to provide NSO habitat while not threatening public safety.

50T

Final Environmental Impact Statement

Trinity Post Fire Hazard Reduction and Salvage

that are designated as 'preferred' or 'high-value' both before and after any treatments as part of an
effective management monitoring program for impacts of logging on NSO. This should always
include multiple site visits within one breeding season, as spotted owls can be occupying a site
but unresponsive during a survey (see every published peer-reviewed occupancy paper from

Response: LOP exemption areas were established in close coordination with the US Fish and

of the project to achieve the Purpose and Need. They were established only where less than ten
percent of the area is "selected for" or "highly selected for" by NSO (using the USFWS NSO
Relative Habitat Suitability model). Some of these areas include territories where nesting or pair
bonding was observed at some point in the past. To further reduce the potential for effects to NSO
reproduction at these sites, the high-value core areas will be subject to LOPs unless stand
searches (as per the NSO survey protocol) are conducted and non-nesting is determined. The
effects analysis incorporates all of these assumptions and discloses the assumptions. If there is
limited information then the effects are assumed to be the worst case scenario.

Comment: Overall this was quite a poor representation of the literature about fire and spotted

the assessment).
Response: The analysis in the BA is based on a thorough review of the scientific literature on the
use of burned areas by spotted owls (California and Mexican spotted owls as well as Northern
spotted owls), and incorporates the recent synthesis of this literature prepared by the US Fish and
Wildlife Service, the agency of expertise for recovery of threatened and endangered species (US
Fish and Wildlife Service 2016). It also makes use of a similar synthesis prepared by Dr. Pat
Manley, a Supervisory Biological Scientist with the US Forest Service (Center for Biological
Diversity et al. v. Susan Skalki and United States Forest Service 2014). These syntheses, and the
analysis in the BA, do not discount the available research. They instead compare research results
and recommendations to identify their similarities and contrasts, as well as their strengths and
weaknesses. Based on this assessment of the best available science, the Forest worked closely
with the US Fish and Wildlife Service to minimize potential effects to NSO while still achieving
the project's Purpose and Need. Published research by the commenter provided an important
contribution to recognizing the use of burned areas by spotted owls. Her work is carefully
considered, and cited extensively in the analysis in the BA. Nevertheless, as is recognized by the
Revised Recovery Plan, high-severity fire remains a major threat to NSO. Roberts et al. 2011 was
reviewed and considered in the analysis, was included in the reference section, and was cited on
page 28 of the BA. This study detected similar rates of occupancy in burned and unburned areas,
although their study sites had predominantly low or moderate fire severity, and also had a limited
history of timber harvest or aggressive wildfire suppression (and thus are likely to have fuels
conditions and fire hazard levels that differ markedly from conditions in our project area). Lee
and Bond 2015 was reviewed and considered in the analysis, was included in the references
section, and was also cited on pages 26 and 47 of the BA.

73. Wild Nature Institute - Monica Bond
50T

Comment: "Perhaps additional, methodically analyzed information about the adverse effects of
post-fire logging on spotted owls is warranted. I present here a recent analysis which was just
completed by Dr. Chad Hanson and submitted to the USFWS on April 18, 2017, which provides
further evidence that large fires are not a major threat to California Spotted Owls (a closely
related subspecies to NSO) and how post-fire logging is in fact a major threat. In the analysis, Dr.
Hanson first analyzed CSO territories that were occupied in the closest year with occupancy data
prior to post-fire logging. For example, the most recent CSO surveys on the San Bernardino
National Forest prior to the Lake fire of 2015 occurred in 2011, whereas in the Rim fire of 2013,
CSO surveys were sporadic prior to the fire, but were extensive beginning in the spring of 2014,
prior to post-fire logging on national forest lands. Dr. Hanson analyzed naïve occupancy of CSO
territories with 50% or more high-severity fire within a 1500-meter radius around territory
centroids at three different levels of post-fire logging-<5%; 5-25%, and >25%. This radius
distance around territory centroids has been found to be important to CSOs for foraging (Bond et
al. 2009). To determine post-fire-logged areas, Dr. Hanson used the Forest Service's FACTS
database, which contains spatially explicit GIS data of post-fire logging activity in any given fire
during any time period, as well as GIS data on fire severity
(https://www.fs.fed.us/postfirevegcondition/whatis.shtml) and land ownership, where forested
moderate- and high-severity fire areas on private lands are consistently post-fire logged (Google
Earth was used to confirm post-fire logging). Dr. Hanson excluded low-severity fire areas, with
low-severity defined consistent with the definition used by the Forest Service (Miller and Thode
2007, Remote Sensing of Environment, Vol. 109, pp. 66-80). In territories dominated by highseverity fire but less than 5% post-fire logging, 7 of 10 CSO territories were occupied (70%
occupancy), whereas only 3 of 11 (27% occupancy) and 1 of 15 (7% occupancy) CSO territories,
dominated by high-severity fire, with 5-25% and >25% post-fire logging, respectively, were
occupied. Using a Chi-square test for trends in binomial proportions, this difference was
statistically significant (c2 = 10.90, p = 0.004, df = 2, n = 36 territories). This indicates that
substantial loss of CSO occupancy following large fires is largely driven by post-fire logging of
complex early seral forest-a habitat type created by high-severity fire effects in mature conifer
forest, and which CSOs select for foraging, given the small mammal prey base in such habitat
(Bond et al. 2009).
598
50T

Final Environmental Impact Statement

Trinity Post Fire Hazard Reduction and Salvage

Second, using all historical CSO territories (i.e., not limited to the ones occupied in the most
recent survey year before post-fire logging), and excluding territories with 5% or more post-fire
logging, Dr. Hanson analyzed overall post-fire naïve occupancy in these large fires, finding 71%
occupancy in the Lake fire (5 of 7), 72% occupancy in the King fire (13 of 18), 94% occupancy
in the Rim fire (33 of 35), 100% occupancy in the Chips fire (9 of 9), 36% occupancy in the Old
fire (4 of 11), and 100% occupancy in the McNally fire (6 of 6) (the Moonlight-Antelope fire was
not included in this analysis because only one territory met the criteria, given the high levels of
post-fire logging that occurred immediately post-fire on private lands in all other CSO territories
in that fire area). These occupancy levels compare very favorably to naïve occupancy levels in the
closest CSO demography study areas to each of these fires, at the times the fires occurred."
Response: The California spotted owl data gathered by Dr. Hanson that is referred to in the
comment, and his reported analysis of that data, is not available as published or peer-reviewed
scientific information. It was submitted to the US Fish and Wildlife Service in the form of a
comment letter rather than a scientific report, and it's validity and applicability to the analysis in
the BA for this project is therefore uncertain at this time. The reported conclusions of Dr. Hanson
are similar to those included in scientific publications co-authored by the commenter (Ms. Bond)
and others that were considered in the analysis for this project and included in the references
section of the BA. These findings are not discounted in the BA, but are instead considered
alongside other works that reached different conclusions. The analysis in the BA assesses the full
range of literature on this subject, and identifies the findings that are well-supported by the
available science on this topic.

Comment: NSO have been demonstrated using severely burned forests, and cutting down trees

reduce risks to travelers while being cautionary about protecting habitat for NSO and helping

Response: The potential adverse effects of cutting snags in NSO habitat are fully analyzed in the
project wildlife BA and wildlife report, which disclose that the overall determination for effects to
NSO and NSO critical habitat is "may affect, likely to adversely affect" under all of the action
alternatives. Numerous resource protection measures have been adopted to reduce effects to NSO
while still allowing the project's Purpose and Need to be met. The project only impacts 5-10% of
the area affected by wildfire (depending on alternative) and no nesting, roosting, or foraging
habitat will be downgraded or removed as a result of project implementation for any action
alternative. The project meets all requirements of the Endangered Species Act, including the
requirement for Federal agencies to "utilize their authorities in furtherance of the purposes of this
Act by carrying out programs for the conservation of endangered species and threatened species"
(ESA Sec. 7. [16 U.S.C. 1536]). It also meets the requirements of the Forest Plan, including the
following: "Forest Service activities and programs are intended to assist in the recovery of T&E
species and to avoid actions that may cause a species to become threatened or endangered"
(Forest Plan p. 3-26); and "T&E species will continue to be managed under existing recovery
goals identified in individual species recovery plans" (Forest Plan, pg. 3-28). See a discussion of
Revised Recovery Plan consistency in Appendix 1 of the BA. The Forest considered an
alternative similar to this but eliminated it from detailed study. Alternative 7b will be developed,
but due to not meeting the Purpose and Need it will not be studied in detail.

79. C itizens For Better Forestry - Joseph Bower
50T

Comment: "The time required to produce this EIS has caused the project to be a failure because
of deterioration of the burned timber. No buyers are likely to bid. The economics of this project
show logging costs exceed the timber value even if the project had been sold while value
remained, soon after the fire. The cost of preparing this EIS is likely to exceed one million
dollars. It makes little sense to further pursue a project like this.
50T

600

Final Environmental Impact Statement

Trinity Post Fire Hazard Reduction and Salvage

Scarce dollars should not be spent on salvage in this instance, and would be better spent on the
roadside fuel breaks and plantation thinning proposed by the TCCG. This salvage is a bad
investment for the US Forest Service to make.
Assuming the project does not sell, please identify what source of funds will be used to remove
roadside hazard trees from the project area?"
Response: The Forest acknowledges the substantial loss of value due to deterioration of burned
timber, and the tenuous economic viability inherent in fire killed trees in the Vegetation and
Economic sections of Chapter 3 of the EIS. Circumstances beyond the Forest's control have
delayed the ROD, but that doesn't invalidate the Purpose and Need for action. The Purpose and
Need of the project is to mitigate hazards that threaten public safety along open roads, sustain and
establish forest cover, and capture economic value if it exists. The need to provide for public
safety is still present and the Forest is committed to addressing this concern. It is not a valid
assumption to say that there will be no economic offset for this project if the timing prevents the
material being sold as saw logs. The continued deterioration of trees impacts the ability to sell
saw log type material, but the market for biomass and other types of utilization do not have the
same thresholds for viability and there continues to be interest in material long after the more
traditional timeline of salvage. The rate that is paid for biomass and other types of utilization is
substantially less than saw log prices, which is why there is a push to try and capture this
opportunity to meet the needs of the project and not shift the burden to the taxpayers to the
greatest extent possible. Assuming timber sale revenue is not generated from the project, the
Forest will utilize appropriated dollars (including its own work force) and pursue supplemental
funding as opportunities arise. The Forest will continue to look for ways to reduce the cost of
implementation by working with biomass and other types of utilization markets. This project
achieves similar objectives to the roadside fuel treatment buffer portion of the "Pilot Project"
referenced in the comment and would neither replace nor delay its priority status within the
Forest's program of work, as designed.

climate as trees mature (Millar et al. 2007)."

Final Environmental Impact Statement

Trinity Post Fire Hazard Reduction and Salvage

The only detail in the DEIS concerning LSRs at page 7 reads:
The LSRA's Chapter 4 includes Activity Design Criterion #7 Fuel Reduction (primarily dead and
down) for which the objective is to remove dead and dying trees in order to protect the remaining
existing and developing late-successional habitat and to facilitate the development of reforested
areas toward late-successional conditions following a stand-replacing event. This criterion applies
to:
a. Areas greater than 10-acres that have received a stand-replacing event (such as wildfire)
resulting in a canopy closure of less than 40%, and includes the following treatment standards:
b. All standing live trees should be retained, including those injured (e.g., scorched) but likely to
survive;
c. Following stand-replacing disturbance, management should focus on retaining snags that are
likely to persist until late-successional conditions have developed and the new stand is again
producing large snags. The biomass left in snags can be credited toward the amount of coarse
woody debris biomass needed to achieve management objectives; and
d. Removal of snags and logs may be necessary to reduce hazards to humans along roads and
trails, and in or adjacent to campgrounds. Where materials must be removed from the site, as in a
campground or on a road, a salvage sale is appropriate. In other areas, such as along roads,
leaving material on site may be considered. (Emphasis added)"
Response: The NWFP describes that a management assessment should be prepared for each large
LSR (or group of smaller LSRs) before habitat manipulation activities are designed and
implemented. In 1999, the Forest prepared the Forestwide Late-Successional Reserve Assessment
(LSRA), which met this requirement. The LSRA activity design criteria identify specific
objectives and criteria to ensure consistency with LSR objectives. In their August 26, 1999 letter
that documents review of the LSRA, the REO determined that the silvicultural activities
described in the LSRA were consistent with the standards and guidelines of the NWFP and were
exempted from further project-level REO review, which met the obligation of REO/RIEC review
of thinning or other silvicultural activities. As the comment indicates, the project has been
designed to be consistent with the Forestwide LSRA, especially relevant is Activity Design
Criterion #7 which addresses actions following a stand replacing event such as a wildfire. The
LSRA also describes the existing and desired conditions for each LSR and their value as part of
the LSR network, as is generally quoted in the comment. However, the LSRA does not serve as a
commitment to analyze the LSR, a land allocation under the Forest Plan, at the project level, but
to serve as guidance document for management. The existing condition of the project area,
including LSRs, is discussed throughout the EIS. This project is consistent with the LSRA and
was designed to promote hazard mitigation, maintain and establish forest cover, and capture value
through providing forest products within the narrow roadside buffers along open roads. It is
unclear why the commenter requests the LSR land allocation be further stratified into another
analysis of existing conditions. As indicated in the comment, connectivity of late successional
habitat was an important theme in LSR designation. Therefore, fragmentation is an important
concept to consider and played a role in project design. The project will not downgrade any NSO
nesting/roosting, foraging or dispersal habitat, and connectivity between these habitats will thus
be maintained. A small amount of PFF habitat will be downgraded or removed. However, these
habitats lack the overhead canopy cover that facilitates connectivity between suitable habitats. As
a result, effects to PFF habitats are not expected to have any meaningfully measurable effect on
habitat connectivity. Also it is important to note that landing construction is not inconsistent with
LSR objectives. Landing construction is a necessary and connected action to forest management
involving any timber removal, which is also consistent with LSR goals and objectives if designed
deliberately for hazard reduction purposes and to promote long term sustainability of late
successional forests. In the case of this project, landing construction is limited to 0.25 acres each,
and will generally use the existing roadside or turnouts or areas of concentrated dead snags
already designated for hazard felling. New landings are described and quantified in the BA, but

are not mapped because their locations are not known at this time. However, an opening of such a
small size is not likely to convert a patch of suitable NSO habitat to unsuitable habitat. Openings
of this size are instead often considered to enhance NSO foraging opportunities within both
nesting/roosting and foraging habitats. They are also not considered a meaningfully measurable
impediment to NSO dispersal. Individual habitat elements may be removed for landings in small
non-contiguous patches but the degree to which this occurs is not expected to affect the
functionality of habitat. Note that any new landing construction is temporary and will be tilled
and mulched following use.

Comment: In looking at Table 3-62, "Comparison of impacts of the action alternatives that are
considered in detail," it is clear that at maximum only 1,400 acres of the 8,000 acres of treatment
burned at high to moderate severity. The footnote at page 305 states, "For this report (Economic)

approximately 700 acres of the 8,000 acres analyzed in the proposed action, were identified as
having concentrated stands of dead merchantable-sized trees within the road segments identified
for salvage through timber sales. However, whole road segments were identified for salvage
opportunities to capture any other economic value that may occur outside of known concentrated
stands. Along road segments in the project area, there exist situations where there are pockets of
highly concentrated dead trees and areas with less concentrated dead trees that are also posing
hazards to the public in between. These isolated or discontinuous occurrences could also be
captured with salvage removal so the analysis considered the full extent of treatment acres as a
possibility for salvage impacts.

108.

E nvironmental Protection Information Center - Tom Wheeler
50T

Comment: The Fuel Reduction criterion also states that the short-term impact on the LSR/MLSA
must be neutral and that treatment should not diminish habitat suitability now or in the future. All
alternatives would affect northern spotted owl critical habitat and High-Value Wildlife
Conservation Areas, however Alternative 5 has the least impact on LSR habitat.
Response: The Forest Plan provides a general guideline that projects that are neutral or beneficial
to the creation and maintenance of late successional habitat are allowed (Forest Plan 4-39).
However, it does not require that proposed actions have no effect on NSO habitat suitability
within LSRs. As designed, the project, located along a narrow roadside buffer along open roads,
does not downgrade or remove any nesting and roosting or foraging habitat. In addition, fuels
treatments followed by planting where existing conifer cover has been removed by the fire will
accelerate the development of late successional characteristics that otherwise may take decades
for seedlings to establish. The proposed action would have limited short-term effects on habitat
suitability (degrade, but not downgrade) within LSR, but would reduce fire behavior and improve
safe ingress and egress for fire suppression and the public. As a result, it would reduce the
potential for high-severity fire to remove large amounts of NSO habitat in the future, thereby
contributing toward long term habitat sustainability.

110.

E nvironmental Protection Information Center - Tom Wheeler
50T

Comment: We are concerned that the Limited Operating Period exemption will not adequately
mitigate impacts to breeding and nesting owls. We urge the agency to use protocol spot check
surveys, which requires three visits.
Response: Limited operating periods for NSO were established for the majority of the project
area. Exemptions from these LOP's were developed in close coordination with the US Fish and
Wildlife Service (BA pp. 34-35). Their purpose is to facilitate prompt implementation of the
project to respond to the urgent need to abate the danger posed by hazard trees. These exemptions
were established only in areas where less than ten percent of the potential disturbance area is
"selected for" or "highly selected for" in the US Fish and Wildlife Service's NSO Relative Habitat
Suitability modeling. The potential effects of these exemptions on individual NSO's are disclosed
and analyzed in the "Assessing Effects to Individual NSO Territories" section of the BA (pp. 5370) and will also be addressed in the BO from USFWS. The project resource protection measures
also require protocol stand searches in all the high-value NSO core areas that are at least partially
within an LOP exemption area. Spot checks are typically used to supplement protocol NSO
surveys prior to the beginning of surveys in years 3 and 4 of the survey effort. Their coverage
extends out 0.25 mi. from project activities. Stand searches were recommend by USFWS rather
than spot checks. Stand searches use the methodology used for follow-up surveys, which
typically covers a larger radius that 0.25 mi. and are thus more likely to detect NSO farther away
from historic use sites. In the event that NSO nesting activity is observed, LOP's will be
implemented to protect these sites during the NSO breeding season. Although the high-value
NSO core areas within these exemption areas will be subject to stand searches, the determination
reached in the BA is still "may affect, likely to adversely affect" due to the possibility of
disturbance during the NSO breeding season.

113.
50T

Comment: We are concerned that the project will affect the Bald Eagles and Northern Goshawk
nest sites on Browns Creek should Limited Operating Periods (LOPs) be lifted without protocol
surveys. The DEIS for both species states on page 109 that, "Surveys to protocol can be used to
generate new breeding activity results. If subsequent protocol compliant surveys show no nesting
activity within 0.75/0.5 (respectively) miles of proposed activities at the time of implementation,
LOPs may be lifted." Our concern here lies with the word can and in order to meet the Standards
and Guidelines in the Forest Plan it should be replaced with the word must or will. Please provide
this clarification in the FEIS.
Response: The intent of the language in these RPMs is to state that LOPs cannot be lifted unless
protocol surveys are completed. There no requirement to conduct protocol surveys for NSO, but
any suitable habitat is considered occupied. The LOPs are RPMs that are included to reduce
impacts. The RPM states, "If subsequent protocol compliant surveys show no nesting activity
within 0.75/0.5 (respectively) miles of proposed activities at the time of implementation, LOPs
may be lifted." This statement indicates that although LOPs may be lifted in this situation,
managers might choose not to lift them. Replacing the word "may" with "must" or "will" would
require managers to lift the LOP if protocol surveys showed no nesting activity within 0.75/0.5
miles of proposed activities at the time of implementation. The LOPs in the RPMs for goshawks,
peregrine falcons, and bald eagles are from the habitat capability models in Appendix G of the
Forest Plan.

Comment: "Portions of ten (HUC 5) watersheds on the Shasta-Trinity National Forest burned in
the 2015 fires. All of the HUC 5 watersheds are listed as sediment-impaired under section 303(d)
of the Clean Water Act except for the Canyon Creek and New River watersheds. Then at the

majority of the project contains sediment-impaired watersheds.
Seven watersheds comprise the bulk of the fire area; these include Browns Creek, Burnt Ranch,
Lower Hayfork Creek, Lower South Fork Trinity River, Middle South Fork Trinity River, New
River, and Upper Hayfork Creek
(DEIS 161). There are four Tier 1 Key Watersheds within the Project area: Upper South Fork
Trinity River (Hayfork Creek to Headwaters); New River (Mouth to Virgin Creek); North Fork
Trinity River (Mouth to Headwaters); Canyon Creek (Mouth to Headwaters). Tier 1 Key
Watersheds contribute directly to conservation of at risk anadromous salmonids and have a high
potential of being restored as part of a watershed restoration program.
Roads and forest management are significant contributors of sediment to impaired watersheds. In
the South Fork Trinity River sub-basin roads are the most significant cause of management
related sediment production. Management related sources (timber harvest, roads, and
cumulative/other-mass wasting and bank erosion) account for about 35% of the total sediment
(DEIS 163). Lower South Fork Trinity River for Hyampom, the disturbance level is very high
(Physical Sciences Report Table 19). Hyampom is a ""planning watershed,"" and planning
watersheds that are over TOC, regardless of ownership, are not to be further impacted unless they
can be improved with appropriate mitigation measures (Forest Plan, page 4-25) (DEIS 163).
Middle South Fork Trinity River is a Key Watershed and is also planning watershed. For the
Upper Middle Trinity River area (including Browns Creek), about 57% of the sediment yield was
management related, with roads being a slightly greater cause than timber harvest. For the Lower

as sediment impaired under section 303(d) of the Clean Water Act. It is not correct to say that
there are four Key Watersheds within the project area. There are two Key Watersheds in the
project area: Upper South Fork Trinity River and New River Key Watersheds lie within the
project area. The North Fork Trinity River Key Watershed lies outside of the project area. Canyon
Creek watershed lies within the project area, but its boundary does not match the Canyon Creek
Key Watershed. Canyon Creek Key Watershed lies outside of the project area. The DEIS (pg.
182) and Fisheries BA will be updated to reflect this distinction. Road reconstruction and type of
use would be the same for all action alternatives because the requirement to treat legacy sediment
sites is based on the project area. The Waiver requirement of treating legacy sediment sites within
the project area for Category B projects does not consider whether or not a site is in an impaired
watershed, or whether or not it is in a Key Watershed. However, treatment prioritization is
required in the Waiver Application, and the Shasta-Trinity National Forest does consider sediment
sites located in impaired watersheds and Key Watersheds to be high priorities for treatment.
However, these are not the only factors that are considered in prioritizing treatment. Other factors
include: priority watershed, poor quality aquatic habitat, critical coho habitat, highly erodible and
unstable bedrock geology, large fill volume, large diversion potential, and cost. Final
prioritization of the legacy sediment sites to be treated will be established in the Waiver
Application after the Record of Decision is signed. Treatment acres that occur in Riparian
Reserves are disclosed by alternative in Table 2-2 of the DEIS (pg. 41).

E nvironmental Protection Information Center - Tom Wheeler

Comment: "We encourage the agency to examine the soil compaction monitoring reports from
other national forests that clearly show long-lasting and significant soil damage from tractor
piling this includes the Payette and Kootenai National Forest. Manual piling or underburning is
far preferable to tractor piling and have none of the negative impacts to soils associated with
tractor piling. Hence manual piling or underburning would better achieve the stated purpose and
need for the project.
Heavy machine use causes soil compaction and displacement. Soil compaction is an increase in
bulk density with a corresponding decrease in soil porosity. Compaction reduces soil productivity
through a reduction in tree root growth, (Graecen and Sands 1980 (1); Froehlich and McNabb
1984 (2)) and may be produced by a single pass of logging equipment across a site (Wronski
1984 (3)). Productivity losses have been documented for whole sites (West and Thomas 1981 (4))
and height, and timber volume (Greacen for individual trees (Froehlich 1979 (5), Helms and
Hipkin 1986 (6)). Decreases in important microbial populations have also been observed in
compacted soils (Amaranthus et al. 1996.) (7) Soil compaction may also increase surface runoff
because of reducing infiltration (Graecen and Sands 1980.) (8).
Soil displacement from ground-based machine use occurs when the tracked equipment turns on
its skids pushing the soil into small piles, or berms, along the skid trails. This displacement of the
topsoil removes the organic litter layer and exposes mineral soil. Removal of the loose, organic
surface materials promotes surface sealing and crusting that decreases infiltration capacity and
may increase erosion (Child et. Al. 1989.) (9) Soil displacement also results in a loss of important
soil biota, such as mycorrhizal fungi, which facilitates nutrient uptake by plants (Amaranthus et
al. 1989 and 1996.) (10)".
Response: Compaction and displacement happens during all mechanical operations (salvage,
thinning, mastication, etc.) using tractors, excavators, skidders, etc. but compaction and
displacement are only problematic when they are so extensive and severe that they are
detrimental to soil health. The Forest Plan Soil Quality Standards, found in Appendix O, focus on
the issue of extent and severity of soil impacts.
The National Forest Management Act of 1976 (NFMA)
(http://www.fs.fed.us/emc/nfma/includes/NFMA1976.pdf) recognized the fundamental need to
protect and, where appropriate, improve the quality of soil, water, and air resources. With respect
to soils, NFMA requires that the Forest Service manage lands so as not to impair their long-term
productivity. Further, activities must be monitored to ensure that productivity is protected. This
law led to subsequent regulation and policy to execute the law at various levels of management.
The National Soil Management Handbook (USDA Forest Service, 1991) defines soil productivity
and components of soil productivity, and establishes guidance for measuring soil productivity. "In
determining a significant change in productivity, a 15% reduction in inherent soil productivity
50T

50T

50T

50T

50T

50T

614

Final Environmental Impact Statement

Trinity Post Fire Hazard Reduction and Salvage

potential will be used as a basis for setting threshold values. Threshold values would apply to
measurable or observable soil properties or conditions that are sensitive to significant change. The
threshold values, along with areal extent limits, would serve as an early warning signal of reduced
soil productive capacity, where changes to management practices or rehabilitation measures may
be warranted. “Management activities have potential to cause various types and degrees of
disturbance. Soil disturbance is categorized into compaction, displacement, puddling, severe
burning, and erosion. Direction was established that properties, measures, and thresholds relative
to these disturbance types would be developed at the Regional and Forest levels, known as Soil
Quality Standards. The 1995 Region 5 Soil Management Handbook Supplement (superseded by
FSM 2550) helped to establish the forest objectives for the Soil Management Program and Soil
Quality Analysis Standards (SQAS).
These analysis standards are intended to help determine if ecosystem health and long-term
productivity are being maintained. SQAS provide measures and threshold values that indicate
when changes in soil properties and soil conditions may result in significant change or
impairment of key soil functions of soil productivity and hydrologic function. Soil disturbance is
considered "detrimental" if thresholds are exceeded and subsequent impairment of soil functions
is judged likely after a soil & site specific assessment. Detrimental disturbance refers to the
severity of impacts, which may be very small scale in occurrence. The extent of detrimental soil
disturbance shall not be of a size or pattern that would result in a significant change in key soil
functions for the activity area. Note that the activity area is the scale at which impacts are
ultimately assessed, defined as the area where soil disturbing activities take place, such as a
timber harvest unit in a sale area or a burn area within a prescribed burn project; system roads,
trails, and other areas not dedicated to growing vegetation (other dedicated uses) are not included
as part of an activity area.
Both severity and extent of detrimental disturbance are important considerations that must be
evaluated together to assess potential adverse impacts on soils of the activity area. As such,
detrimental disturbance can be allowed on a small portion of a unit - this does not constitute
adverse impacts; conversely, minor disturbance can be allowed in most of a unit - this likewise
does not constitute adverse impacts. Aerial extent limits for different disturbance types are not
established in the R5 handbook supplement. In 2010 the Shasta-Trinity National Forest (Forest)
adopted the National Soil Disturbance Monitoring Protocol (NSDMP) (Page-Dumroese, et. al.
2009) level one analysis (visual soil disturbance indicators) along with developing a level two
analysis (validation sampling) using transects to measure erosion, disturbance, compaction,
displacement, and cover (Rust, 2011). Past project activities on the Forest (Rust, 2015) show
when fine-textured and coarse-textured soils are operated on with track-based mechanical
equipment when dry (less than 20% soil moisture by weight), compaction levels never exceeded
10% decrease in soil porosity. But when soils were moist (greater than 20% soil moisture by
weight) compaction levels on fine-textured soils were exceeded over the 15% Forest Plan aerial
extent.
Resource Protection Measures, particularly 44, 45, 47, and 52 i(n the DEIS) will ensure that that
soil compaction is within the soil quality standards. For machine-piling, monitoring results on the
Forest showed minimal soil impacts from machine piling and burning using small tractors fitted
with brush rakes, which is the typical type of equipment used on NFS lands in Trinity County.
Soil burning and soil displacement was minimal and soil compaction from machine-piling was
minimal only adding 2 to 4% increase in bulk density (Rust, 2013).
Machine piling earned a reputation as a harmful practice on soils in the past from the era where
machine piling almost exclusively referred to site preparation for planting after a clear-cut, often
occurring on moderately steep slopes. Impacts from tractor piling can be high if done improperly,
especially on wet soils, but research conducted on the Shasta Trinity National Forest has shown
that, on average, tractor piling added 2 percent detrimental soil disturbance as displacement and
compaction to the activity units when conducted on dry soils (Powers and Young, 2005).

50T

Final Environmental Impact Statement

Trinity Post Fire Hazard Reduction and Salvage

On the Shasta-Trinity National Forest, tractor-piling operations are mostly conducted on slopes
less than 35%. For this project, machine piling will only be allowed on slopes less than 40%
(RPM #62 in the DEIS). Much smaller tractors equipped with a brush rake on the blade are
expected to be used for this project, which result in little to no topsoil displacement or
compaction that would be of any detrimental degree. Piles are to be "clean" (without soil), which
helps them burn properly. Tractor piling has been examined extensively on the Forest and when
soils are dry impacts are minimal and well below the Forest Plan Soil Quality Standards (Rust,
2013). This is ensured by the soil resource protection measures for this project (listed in the
Physical Science report pg. 118).
Heavy machine use can cause soil compaction, as evidenced by the following studies: Tree and
Sands 1980; Froehlich and McNabb 1984; Wronski 1984; West and Thomas 1981; Greacen and
Froehlich 1979; Helms and Hipkin 1986; Amaranthus et al. 1996; Graecen and Sands 1980. Soil
quality standards and soil resource protection measures will ensure soils are dry enough for
mechanical operations to support equipment without causing detrimental soil impacts of
compaction.
Soil displacement from ground-based machines has also been observed in the studies cited: Child
et. Al. 1989; Amaranthus et al. 1989 and 1996. Again all of this is known and true but the real
issue is when operations take place, are the soils wet or very moist or are the soils dry? This is
why we have the soil quality standards and soil resource protection measures to ensure soils are
dry enough for mechanical operations to support equipment without causing detrimental soil
impacts of displacement.
On steeper ground (>35% slope), manual piling and underburning will be used to reduce fuels. If
burned at low to moderate burn intensity little soil impacts occur. For machine-piling and burning
the key is soil moisture (bearing strength) when soils are dry enough so little displacement and
compaction occur. Machine-piling is fast and effective in managing excessive fuels and when
soils are dry impacts are minimal. Also tractor-piling is safer for personnel in regards to larger
fuels in the difficulty of staking those fuels. By use of the Soil Moisture Operability field Guide
(Rust, 2009) soils are tested before operations to insure soils are dry enough for heavy equipment
operations so soil quality standards are not exceeded.

Soil Effects Monitoring. On file at Shasta-Trinity National Forest, Redding, CA. 5p.Rust, B.
2009. Field Guide for Soil Moisture Operability. On file at Shasta-Trinity National Forest,

Comment: "Unclear if Project Meets Purpose and Need
It is unclear whether the salvage component meets the stated purpose and need of the project. A
purpose of the project is to ""[c]apture economic value and support the economies of local
communities by providing forest products."" (DEIS at 4). EPIC reads this purpose to mean a
project that captures economic value for both the Forest Service and any private timber
purchasers. Similarly, a stated need of the project is to ""[q]uickly recover the monetary value of
618

Final Environmental Impact Statement

Trinity Post Fire Hazard Reduction and Salvage

wood through salvage and sale, where feasible and appropriate, to provide economic stimulus to
local communities."" (DEIS at 5, citing Forest Plan 4-5).
To be frank, large projects take a long time. There are numerous steps that must be taken before
implementation can begin: the Shasta-Trinity will need to produce the Final Environmental
Impact Statement and the Record of Decision (ROD); and complete consultation with the U.S.
Fish and Wildlife Service; and be enrolled by the North Coast Regional Water Quality Control
Board under a waiver. Looking to another large post-fire project on the Klamath National Forest
(KNF) helps to illustrate probable timeline. The Westside Fire Recovery Project DEIS was issued
on March 5, 2015 and the ROD was signed February 29, 2016.
Here, the project DEIS was on March 17, 2017. Based on a reasonable timeline it is likely that
logging would not begin until 2018. Even if the timeline was shortened and begin in 2017, it is
likely that logging would run into wet weather restrictions.
As is clear from the DEIS and Economic Report, ""due to deterioration, it's expected that the
Project will be deficit -$476,527 if the investment is made within the 2017 calendar year."" (DEIS
at 309; see also id. at 310). EPIC is unclear how a deficit sale fits the purpose and need for the
project. Overestimating Timber Value
EPIC is concerned that the Forest Service is basing its economic analysis off too rosy of
projections of potential revenue. The DEIS repeatedly acknowledges that ""[m]any fire-killed tree
species will lose a significant portion of their monetary value and volume for products in a very
short time."" The DEIS provides value per tree species based on data from the 2015 Western
Wood Products Summary. (DEIS at 306, Table 3-96). On average, the DEIS predicts an average
value of $377.03/mbf. The DEIS further acknowledges that price/mbf will diminish over time as
the timber deteriorates. (DEIS at 309). The Forest Service never clearly states what revenue, as
measured in $/mbf, it expects. Please provide a clear estimate of revenue, measured both in $/mbf
and in total dollar amounts in the final EIS.
EPIC is concerned that the revenue estimated by the Shasta-Trinity is too high.
The only mills that will purchase substantially deteriorated post-fire timber are veneer mills to be
used as interior layers in plywood. The DEIS acknowledges that the only mill in Trinity County is
the Trinity River Lumber Company. (DEIS at 303). The Trinity River Lumber Company produces
structural timber products not plywood veneer. In their comments, the Trinity Lumber Company
wrote, ""In order to quickly recover value this project needs to be fully executed and operated by
early summer 2016."
Response: The third component of the Project's purpose is to capture economic value and support
the economies of local communities by providing forest products. The purpose and need does not
specify a minimum threshold, as is evident with the inclusion of Alternative 5, which does not
include a commercial salvage component. However, the availability of commercial firewood
removal, small timber sales, biomass, etc., to the local communities would still meet that purpose.
Salvage timber sales are a tool for reducing hazard trees and treating fuels in a more costeffective manner by capturing the economic value of fire-killed trees. Even when the value of the
timber is less than the cost of abating the hazard, timber value can help offset some of the costs of
hazard mitigation. The economics report focused on the sawtimber value as that is a tangible
means of comparing likely salvage treatments. At some point, however, there is not enough
monetary value in wood products to support the cost of harvesting and processing that wood. The
economics report shows when that is likely to occur and how it affects jobs and wages in the local
community. The Western Woods Products Association (WWPA) feeds into the base indices for
assessing timber value ($/CCF) by species. Utilizing these base indices, individual timber sale
offerings will have a project specific appraisal calculated prior to advertisement which
incorporates cruise volume data, deterioration factors, haul distance, and other adjustments
(landing decommissioning, subsoiling main skid trails, etc.). However, the WWPA index is the
standard way to calculate the estimated value of timber at this time. See Tables 3-97 and 3-98 of

Final Environmental Impact Statement

Trinity Post Fire Hazard Reduction and Salvage

the DEIS for revenue estimations by alternative, over time. Additionally, review the Effects
Analysis for relative comparisons across proposed actions. The Forest acknowledges that
planning and implementing large EISs such as this Project incorporates many steps and has a
complicated timeline. The Forest is aware of all the steps identified by the commenter. The Forest
is committed to moving forward as efficiently as possible while producing a thorough and
thoughtful analysis.

Environmental Protection Information Center - Tom Wheeler

Comment: "Salvage Will Make Project More Expensive to Implement
Salvage without treating post-logging fuels would make fuel conditions worse in the immediate
future compared to no action at all. For this reason, the Trinity Salvage Project proposed postsalvage fuel reduction treatments. Alternatives 1, 2, 3, and 4 all would require post-logging slash
treatment that could cost more than the revenue from logging.
The DEIS concludes, ""Salvage harvest alone does not significantly reduce fire behavior (Donato
et al. 2006)."" In fact, Donato et al. 2006 found that salvage made fuel conditions worse in the
immediate future. Timber harvesting, including post-fire ""salvage"" logging, is known to
increase surface fuels loads by transferring non-merchantable trees, limbs, tops and other
""slash"" to the surface (Donato et. al 2006, Donato et al. 2012; Keyser et al. 2009; McGinnis et
al. 2010). These elevated surface fuels may persist for ~20 years (McIver and Ottman 2007;
McGinnis et al. 2010).
EPIC anticipates high amounts of slash from this project. Because only large diameter snags are
likely to retain sufficient value to recoup costs in harvesting and transportation, there are likely to
be many snags that will not go to market. As is often the case, a timber company will fell all trees,
including those that they do not anticipate bringing to market, because it decreases risks to
loggers. Post-fire salvage logging is likely to result in higher than normal amounts of slash,
including jackpotted fuels that take additional time to decompose as most of the fuel is not in
contact with the ground.
However, as acknowledged by the DEIS, the cost to clean up those units after salvage logging
will be more expensive because of the necessary fuel treatments. If logging occurred in 2017,
post-logging slash treatment would cost $476,527 for Alternative 1, $625,644 for Alternative 2,
$947,054 for Alternative 3, and $130,159 for Alternative 4. While logging may provide some jobs
to the local community, it would make project completion more difficult by increasing the total
costs to the Forest Service."
Response: Alternatives 1, 2, 3, & 4 combine felling of standing dead trees with surface fuel
treatments. Surface fuel treatments without felling of standing dead trees would temporarily
reduce fuel loading, but as the standing dead trees fell, surface fuel accumulations would
increase. Treating surface fuels beneath standing dead trees could expose workers to unsafe
conditions. Salvage activities can result in further accumulations of surface fuels. Secondary fuel
treatments are intended to reduce that loading to meet the desired condition. For Alternatives 1, 2,
3, and 4, salvage units will have secondary fuels treatments. The Donato et al. paper has been
disputed by Newton et al. 2006, which stated that the paper lacks adequate context and supporting
information to be clearly interpreted by scientists, resource managers, policy-makers, and the
public. Donato found salvage without secondary fuels treatments made things worse, as breakage,
limbs and tops were left on site, increasing fire behavior and effect should another fire burn
through the area. This project implements secondary fuels treatments to achieve the desired
condition in all salvage units. In some areas, because of the severity of the wildfire, some limbs,
tops, and breakage need to be left for resource needs. Post-harvest fuels that are left on site would
not exceed the maximum of 20 tons per acre which would maintain desired fire behavior and
effects should a future fire burn through the treatment area. Secondary fuels treatments would be
funded through multiple sources, including timber receipts, retained receipts, appropriated funds,
and any others that come available. Donato et al. 2012 indicated that post-fire logging altered the
620

Final Environmental Impact Statement

Trinity Post Fire Hazard Reduction and Salvage

fuel profile of early-seral stands (standing material removed or transferred, short-term increase in
surface fuels, likely reduction in future large fuel accumulation), with moderate-intensity and
unlogged treatments yielding surface fuel loads consistent with commonly prescribed levels, and
high-intensity treatment resulting in greater potential need for follow-up fuel treatments. The
paper also recommends a greater potential need for follow-up fuel treatments, which has been
incorporated into this projects design. Keyser et al. 2009 examined the impacts of post-fire
salvage logging on regeneration, fuel accumulation, and understory vegetation and assessed
whether the effects of salvage logging differed between stands burned under moderate and high
fire severity following the 2000 Jasper Fire in the Black Hills. The paper found no discernible
effect of salvage logging on understory development 5 years after fire. Logging caused neither a
reduction in total plant cover nor an increase in the abundance of exotic species. They also
recognize that there is less coarse woody debris (CWD) in salvage units compared to nontreatment units. The paper did not mention secondary fuels treatments. McGinnis et al. 2010
noted that logging fire-killed trees significantly increased total available dead fuel loads in the
short term but did not affect shrub cover, grass and forb cover, alien species cover or alien species
richness. The paper did not indicate if secondary fuels treatments were implemented. McIver and
Ottmar 2007 found logging significantly reduced tree density, especially for the smallest (<22 cm
diameter) and intermediate (23-41 cm) diameter classes. Fuel reduction units also had
significantly fewer snags (dead trees >30 cm diameter—4 per hectare), compared to both
commercial (23 per hectare) units and to un-logged controls (64 per hectare) in the year following
timber harvest. Logging did not change ladder height or tree species composition (% ponderosa
pine, Douglas-fir and grand fir). Total woody fuel mass increased significantly in fuel reduction
units when compared to controls, with the greatest difference among treatments occurring in the
slash fuel (<7.6 cm diameter) component (mean of 6.2 Mg/ha for fuel reduction stands versus 1.3
Mg/ha for un-logged stands). This paper did not consider secondary fuels treatments.
